      <p>
       <b>
        YouTube
       </b>
       is an American
       <a href="/wiki/Video_hosting_service" title="Video hosting service">
        video-sharing
       </a>
       website headquartered in
       <a href="/wiki/San_Bruno,_California" title="San Bruno, California">
        San Bruno, California
       </a>
       . The service was created by three former
       <a href="/wiki/PayPal" title="PayPal">
        PayPal
       </a>
       employees—
       <a href="/wiki/Chad_Hurley" title="Chad Hurley">
        Chad Hurley
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Steve_Chen" title="Steve Chen">
        Steve Chen
       </a>
       , and
       <a href="/wiki/Jawed_Karim" title="Jawed Karim">
        Jawed Karim
       </a>
       —in February 2005.
       <a href="/wiki/Google" title="Google">
        Google
       </a>
       bought the site in November 2006 for US$1.65 billion; YouTube now operates as one of Google's
       <a href="/wiki/Subsidiary" title="Subsidiary">
        subsidiaries
       </a>
       .
      </p>
      <p>
       YouTube allows users to upload, view, rate, share, add to favorites, report, comment on videos, and
       <a href="/wiki/List_of_most-subscribed_YouTube_channels" title="List of most-subscribed YouTube channels">
        subscribe to other users
       </a>
       . It offers a wide variety of
       <a href="/wiki/User-generated_content" title="User-generated content">
        user-generated
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Corporate_media" title="Corporate media">
        corporate media
       </a>
       videos. Available content includes
       <a href="/wiki/Video_clip" title="Video clip">
        video clips
       </a>
       ,
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/TV_show" title="TV show">
        TV show
       </a>
       clips,
       <a href="/wiki/Music_video" title="Music video">
        music videos
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Short_film" title="Short film">
        short
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Documentary_film" title="Documentary film">
        documentary
       </a>
       films, audio recordings,
       <a href="/wiki/Trailer_(promotion)" title="Trailer (promotion)">
        movie trailers
       </a>
       ,
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Live_streams" title="Live streams">
        live streams
       </a>
       , and other content such as
       <a href="/wiki/Video_blog" title="Video blog">
        video blogging
       </a>
       , short original videos, and
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Edutainment" title="Edutainment">
        educational videos
       </a>
       . Most of the content on YouTube is uploaded by individuals, but media corporations including
       <a href="/wiki/CBS" title="CBS">
        CBS
       </a>
       , the
       <a href="/wiki/BBC" title="BBC">
        BBC
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Vevo" title="Vevo">
        Vevo
       </a>
       , and
       <a href="/wiki/Hulu" title="Hulu">
        Hulu
       </a>
       offer some of their material via YouTube as part of the YouTube partnership program. Unregistered users can only watch videos on the site, while registered users are permitted to upload an unlimited number of videos and add comments to videos. Videos deemed potentially inappropriate are available only to registered users affirming themselves to be at least 18 years old.
      </p>
      <p>
       YouTube earns advertising revenue from Google
       <a href="/wiki/AdSense" title="AdSense">
        AdSense
       </a>
       , a program which targets ads according to site content and audience. The vast majority of its videos are free to view, but there are exceptions, including subscription-based premium channels, film rentals, as well as
       <a href="/wiki/YouTube_Red" title="YouTube Red">
        YouTube Red
       </a>
       , a subscription service offering ad-free access to the website and access to exclusive content made in partnership with existing users. As of February 2017
       <sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;">
        <a class="external text" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=YouTube&amp;action=edit">
         [update]
        </a>
       </sup>
       , there are more than 400 hours of content uploaded to YouTube each minute, and one billion hours of content are watched on YouTube every day. As of August 2017
       <sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;">
        <a class="external text" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=YouTube&amp;action=edit">
         [update]
        </a>
       </sup>
       , the website is ranked as the second-most popular site in the world by
       <a href="/wiki/Alexa_Internet" title="Alexa Internet">
        Alexa Internet
       </a>
       , a web traffic analysis company.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-alexa_1-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-alexa-1">
         [1]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
      </p>
      <div class="toc" id="toc">
       <div class="toctitle" dir="ltr" lang="en">

      <p>
      </p>
      <h2>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Company_history">
        Company history
       </span>
      </h2>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/History_of_YouTube" title="History of YouTube">
        History of YouTube
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:402px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Youtube_founders.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="480" data-file-width="1317" height="146" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c8/Youtube_founders.jpg/400px-Youtube_founders.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c8/Youtube_founders.jpg/600px-Youtube_founders.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c8/Youtube_founders.jpg/800px-Youtube_founders.jpg 2x" width="400"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Youtube_founders.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         From left to right:
         <a href="/wiki/Chad_Hurley" title="Chad Hurley">
          Chad Hurley
         </a>
         ,
         <a href="/wiki/Steve_Chen" title="Steve Chen">
          Steve Chen
         </a>
         and
         <a href="/wiki/Jawed_Karim" title="Jawed Karim">
          Jawed Karim
         </a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       YouTube was founded by
       <a href="/wiki/Chad_Hurley" title="Chad Hurley">
        Chad Hurley
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Steve_Chen" title="Steve Chen">
        Steve Chen
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Jawed_Karim" title="Jawed Karim">
        Jawed Karim
       </a>
       , who were all early employees of
       <a href="/wiki/PayPal" title="PayPal">
        PayPal
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-7">
        <a href="#cite_note-7">
         [7]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Hurley had studied design at
       <a href="/wiki/Indiana_University_of_Pennsylvania" title="Indiana University of Pennsylvania">
        Indiana University of Pennsylvania
       </a>
       , and Chen and Karim studied
       <a href="/wiki/Computer_science" title="Computer science">
        computer science
       </a>
       together at the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/University_of_Illinois_at_Urbana-Champaign" title="University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign">
        University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-8">
        <a href="#cite_note-8">
         [8]
        </a>
       </sup>
       According to a story that has often been repeated in the media, Hurley and Chen developed the idea for YouTube during the early months of 2005, after they had experienced difficulty sharing videos that had been shot at a dinner party at Chen's apartment in San Francisco. Karim did not attend the party and denied that it had occurred, but Chen commented that the idea that YouTube was founded after a dinner party "was probably very strengthened by marketing ideas around creating a story that was very digestible".
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-YouTube_gurus_9-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-YouTube_gurus-9">
         [9]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Karim said the inspiration for YouTube first came from
       <a href="/wiki/Janet_Jackson" title="Janet Jackson">
        Janet Jackson
       </a>
       's role in the 2004
       <a href="/wiki/Super_Bowl_XXXVIII_halftime_show_controversy" title="Super Bowl XXXVIII halftime show controversy">
        Super Bowl incident
       </a>
       , when her breast was exposed during her performance, and later from the
       <a href="/wiki/2004_Indian_Ocean_earthquake_and_tsunami" title="2004 Indian Ocean earthquake and tsunami">
        2004 Indian Ocean tsunami
       </a>
       . Karim could not easily find video clips of either event online, which led to the idea of a video sharing site.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-10">
        <a href="#cite_note-10">
         [10]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Hurley and Chen said that the original idea for YouTube was a video version of an
       <a href="/wiki/Online_dating_service" title="Online dating service">
        online dating service
       </a>
       , and had been influenced by the website
       <a href="/wiki/Hot_or_Not" title="Hot or Not">
        Hot or Not
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-YouTube_gurus_9-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-YouTube_gurus-9">
         [9]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-11">
        <a href="#cite_note-11">
         [11]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Youtube_logo.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="60" data-file-width="280" height="47" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0a/Youtube_logo.jpg/220px-Youtube_logo.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/0/0a/Youtube_logo.jpg 1.5x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Youtube_logo.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         The YouTube logo from launch until 2011, featuring its former slogan
         <i>
          Broadcast Yourself
         </i>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       YouTube began as a
       <a href="/wiki/Venture_capital" title="Venture capital">
        venture capital
       </a>
       -funded technology
       <a href="/wiki/Startup_company" title="Startup company">
        startup
       </a>
       , primarily from an $11.5 million investment by
       <a href="/wiki/Sequoia_Capital" title="Sequoia Capital">
        Sequoia Capital
       </a>
       between November 2005 and April 2006.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-12">
        <a href="#cite_note-12">
         [12]
        </a>
       </sup>
       YouTube's early headquarters were situated above a pizzeria and Japanese restaurant in San Mateo, California.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-13">
        <a href="#cite_note-13">
         [13]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The
       <a href="/wiki/Domain_name" title="Domain name">
        domain name
       </a>
       <code>
        www.youtube.com
       </code>
       was activated on February 14, 2005, and the website was developed over the subsequent months.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-14">
        <a href="#cite_note-14">
         [14]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The first YouTube video, titled
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/Me_at_the_zoo" title="Me at the zoo">
         Me at the zoo
        </a>
       </i>
       , shows co-founder Jawed Karim at the
       <a href="/wiki/San_Diego_Zoo" title="San Diego Zoo">
        San Diego Zoo
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-15">
        <a href="#cite_note-15">
         [15]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The video was uploaded on April 23, 2005, and can still be viewed on the site.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-16">
        <a href="#cite_note-16">
         [16]
        </a>
       </sup>
       YouTube offered the public a beta test of the site in May 2005. The first video to reach one million views was a
       <a href="/wiki/Nike,_Inc." title="Nike, Inc.">
        Nike
       </a>
       advertisement featuring
       <a href="/wiki/Ronaldinho" title="Ronaldinho">
        Ronaldinho
       </a>
       in November 2005.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-17">
        <a href="#cite_note-17">
         [17]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-18">
        <a href="#cite_note-18">
         [18]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Following a $3.5 million investment from Sequoia Capital in November, the site launched officially on December 15, 2005, by which time the site was receiving 8 million views a day.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-19">
        <a href="#cite_note-19">
         [19]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-20">
        <a href="#cite_note-20">
         [20]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The site grew rapidly and, in July 2006, the company announced that more than 65,000 new videos were being uploaded every day, and that the site was receiving 100 million video views per day.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-21">
        <a href="#cite_note-21">
         [21]
        </a>
       </sup>
       According to data published by market research company
       <a href="/wiki/ComScore" title="ComScore">
        comScore
       </a>
       , YouTube is the dominant provider of online video in the United States, with a
       <a href="/wiki/Market_share" title="Market share">
        market share
       </a>
       of around 43% and more than 14 billion views of videos in May 2010.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-22">
        <a href="#cite_note-22">
         [22]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       In May 2011, 48 hours of new videos were uploaded to the site every minute,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-48-60_23-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-48-60-23">
         [23]
        </a>
       </sup>
       which increased to 60 hours every minute in January 2012,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-48-60_23-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-48-60-23">
         [23]
        </a>
       </sup>
       100 hours every minute in May 2013,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-24">
        <a href="#cite_note-24">
         [24]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-25">
        <a href="#cite_note-25">
         [25]
        </a>
       </sup>
       300 hours every minute in November 2014,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-26">
        <a href="#cite_note-26">
         [26]
        </a>
       </sup>
       and 400 hours every minute in February 2017.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-27">
        <a href="#cite_note-27">
         [27]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-28">
        <a href="#cite_note-28">
         [28]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The site has 800 million unique users a month.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-seabrook20120116_29-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-seabrook20120116-29">
         [29]
        </a>
       </sup>
       It is estimated that in 2007 YouTube consumed as much
       <a href="/wiki/Bandwidth_(computing)" title="Bandwidth (computing)">
        bandwidth
       </a>
       as the entire Internet in 2000.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-30">
        <a href="#cite_note-30">
         [30]
        </a>
       </sup>
       According to third-party web analytics providers,
       <a href="/wiki/Alexa_Internet" title="Alexa Internet">
        Alexa
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/SimilarWeb" title="SimilarWeb">
        SimilarWeb
       </a>
       , YouTube is the second-most visited website in the world, as of December 2016
       <sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;">
        <a class="external text" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=YouTube&amp;action=edit">
         [update]
        </a>
       </sup>
       ; SimilarWeb also lists YouTube as the top TV and video website globally, attracting more than 15 billion visitors per month.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-alexa_1-2">
        <a href="#cite_note-alexa-1">
         [1]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-similar_31-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-similar-31">
         [31]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-32">
        <a href="#cite_note-32">
         [32]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       The choice of the name
       <code>
        www.youtube.com
       </code>
       led to problems for a similarly named website,
       <code>
        www.utube.com
       </code>
       . The site's owner,
       <a href="/wiki/Universal_Tube_%26_Rollform_Equipment" title="Universal Tube &amp; Rollform Equipment">
        Universal Tube &amp; Rollform Equipment
       </a>
       , filed a lawsuit against YouTube in November 2006 after being regularly overloaded by people looking for YouTube. Universal Tube has since changed the name of its website to
       <code>
        www.utubeonline.com
       </code>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-33">
        <a href="#cite_note-33">
         [33]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-34">
        <a href="#cite_note-34">
         [34]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In October 2006,
       <a href="/wiki/Google" title="Google">
        Google
       </a>
       Inc. announced that it had acquired YouTube for $1.65 billion in Google stock,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-35">
        <a href="#cite_note-35">
         [35]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-36">
        <a href="#cite_note-36">
         [36]
        </a>
       </sup>
       and the deal was finalized on November 13, 2006.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-37">
        <a href="#cite_note-37">
         [37]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-38">
        <a href="#cite_note-38">
         [38]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:252px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:901_Cherry_Avenue.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2800" data-file-width="5004" height="140" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ec/901_Cherry_Avenue.jpg/250px-901_Cherry_Avenue.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ec/901_Cherry_Avenue.jpg/375px-901_Cherry_Avenue.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ec/901_Cherry_Avenue.jpg/500px-901_Cherry_Avenue.jpg 2x" width="250"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:901_Cherry_Avenue.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         YouTube's headquarters in San Bruno, California
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       In March 2010, YouTube began free streaming of certain content, including 60 cricket matches of the
       <a href="/wiki/Indian_Premier_League" title="Indian Premier League">
        Indian Premier League
       </a>
       . According to YouTube, this was the first worldwide free online broadcast of a major sporting event.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-39">
        <a href="#cite_note-39">
         [39]
        </a>
       </sup>
       On March 31, 2010, the YouTube website launched a new design, with the aim of simplifying the interface and increasing the time users spend on the site. Google product manager Shiva Rajaraman commented: "We really felt like we needed to step back and remove the clutter."
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-40">
        <a href="#cite_note-40">
         [40]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In May 2010, YouTube videos were watched more than two billion times per day.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-41">
        <a href="#cite_note-41">
         [41]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-42">
        <a href="#cite_note-42">
         [42]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-43">
        <a href="#cite_note-43">
         [43]
        </a>
       </sup>
       This increased to three billion in May 2011,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-44">
        <a href="#cite_note-44">
         [44]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-45">
        <a href="#cite_note-45">
         [45]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-46">
        <a href="#cite_note-46">
         [46]
        </a>
       </sup>
       and four billion in January 2012.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-48-60_23-2">
        <a href="#cite_note-48-60-23">
         [23]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-47">
        <a href="#cite_note-47">
         [47]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In February 2017, one billion hours of YouTube was watched every day.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-48">
        <a href="#cite_note-48">
         [48]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-49">
        <a href="#cite_note-49">
         [49]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-50">
        <a href="#cite_note-50">
         [50]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       In October 2010, Hurley announced that he would be stepping down as chief executive officer of YouTube to take an advisory role, and that
       <a href="/wiki/Salar_Kamangar" title="Salar Kamangar">
        Salar Kamangar
       </a>
       would take over as head of the company.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-51">
        <a href="#cite_note-51">
         [51]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In April 2011, James Zern, a YouTube software engineer, revealed that 30% of videos accounted for 99% of views on the site.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-52">
        <a href="#cite_note-52">
         [52]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In November 2011, the
       <a href="/wiki/Google%2B" title="Google+">
        Google+
       </a>
       social networking site was integrated directly with YouTube and the
       <a href="/wiki/Google_Chrome" title="Google Chrome">
        Chrome
       </a>
       web browser, allowing YouTube videos to be viewed from within the Google+ interface.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-53">
        <a href="#cite_note-53">
         [53]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:202px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Logo_of_YouTube_(2015-2017).svg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="211" data-file-width="502" height="84" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e1/Logo_of_YouTube_%282015-2017%29.svg/200px-Logo_of_YouTube_%282015-2017%29.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e1/Logo_of_YouTube_%282015-2017%29.svg/300px-Logo_of_YouTube_%282015-2017%29.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e1/Logo_of_YouTube_%282015-2017%29.svg/400px-Logo_of_YouTube_%282015-2017%29.svg.png 2x" width="200"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Logo_of_YouTube_(2015-2017).svg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         YouTube logo from 2015 until 2017
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       In December 2011, YouTube launched a new version of the site interface, with the video channels displayed in a central column on the home page, similar to the news feeds of social networking sites.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-54">
        <a href="#cite_note-54">
         [54]
        </a>
       </sup>
       At the same time, a new version of the YouTube logo was introduced with a darker shade of red, the first change in design since October 2006.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-55">
        <a href="#cite_note-55">
         [55]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In May 2013, YouTube launched a pilot program to begin offering some content providers the ability to charge $0.99 per month or more for certain channels, but the vast majority of its videos would remain free to view.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-subscription_56-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-subscription-56">
         [56]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-57">
        <a href="#cite_note-57">
         [57]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In February 2014,
       <a href="/wiki/Susan_Wojcicki" title="Susan Wojcicki">
        Susan Wojcicki
       </a>
       was appointed
       <a href="/wiki/Chief_executive_officer" title="Chief executive officer">
        CEO
       </a>
       of YouTube.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-58">
        <a href="#cite_note-58">
         [58]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       In February 2015, YouTube released a secondary mobile app known as
       <a href="/wiki/YouTube_Kids" title="YouTube Kids">
        YouTube Kids
       </a>
       . The app is designed to provide an experience optimized for children, and features a simplified user interface, curated selections of channels featuring age-approriate content (including existing channels and entertainment brands), and parental control features.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-59">
        <a href="#cite_note-59">
         [59]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Later on August 26, 2015, YouTube launched YouTube Gaming—a
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Video_gaming" title="Video gaming">
        video gaming
       </a>
       -oriented sub-site and app that is intended to compete with the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Amazon.com" title="Amazon.com">
        Amazon.com
       </a>
       -owned
       <a href="/wiki/Twitch.tv" title="Twitch.tv">
        Twitch.tv
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-60">
        <a href="#cite_note-60">
         [60]
        </a>
       </sup>
       2015 also saw the announcement of a premium YouTube service titled YouTube Red, which provides users with both ad-free content as well as the ability to download videos among other features.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Youtubered_61-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Youtubered-61">
         [61]
        </a>
       </sup>
       On August 10, 2015, Google announced that it was creating a new company,
       <a href="/wiki/Alphabet_Inc." title="Alphabet Inc.">
        Alphabet
       </a>
       , to act as the
       <a href="/wiki/Holding_company" title="Holding company">
        holding company
       </a>
       for Google, with the change in financial reporting to begin in the fourth quarter of 2015. YouTube remains as a subsidiary of Google.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-62">
        <a href="#cite_note-62">
         [62]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In January 2016, YouTube expanded its headquarters in San Bruno by purchasing an office park for $215 million. The complex has 554,000 square feet of space and can house up to 2,800 employees.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-office_park_63-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-office_park-63">
         [63]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       On August 29, 2017, YouTube launched a new logo, typeface, color scheme and other changes to the appearance of its desktop and mobile app.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-64">
        <a href="#cite_note-64">
         [64]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h2>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Features">
        Features
       </span>
      </h2>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Video_technology">
        Video technology
       </span>
      </h3>
      <p>
       YouTube primarily uses the
       <a href="/wiki/VP9" title="VP9">
        VP9
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/H.264/MPEG-4_AVC" title="H.264/MPEG-4 AVC">
        H.264/MPEG-4 AVC
       </a>
       video formats, and the
       <a href="/wiki/Dynamic_Adaptive_Streaming_over_HTTP" title="Dynamic Adaptive Streaming over HTTP">
        Dynamic Adaptive Streaming over HTTP
       </a>
       protocol.
      </p>
      <h4>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Playback">
        Playback
       </span>
      </h4>
      <p>
       Previously, viewing YouTube videos on a personal computer required the
       <a href="/wiki/Adobe_Flash_Player" title="Adobe Flash Player">
        Adobe Flash Player
       </a>
       plug-in to be installed in the browser.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-65">
        <a href="#cite_note-65">
         [65]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In January 2010, YouTube launched an experimental version of the site that used the built-in multimedia capabilities of web browsers supporting the
       <a href="/wiki/HTML5" title="HTML5">
        HTML5
       </a>
       standard.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-youtubehtml5_66-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-youtubehtml5-66">
         [66]
        </a>
       </sup>
       This allowed videos to be viewed without requiring Adobe Flash Player or any other plug-in to be installed.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-67">
        <a href="#cite_note-67">
         [67]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-68">
        <a href="#cite_note-68">
         [68]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The YouTube site had a page that allowed supported browsers to opt into the HTML5 trial. Only browsers that supported HTML5 Video using the
       <a href="/wiki/MPEG-4_Part_14" title="MPEG-4 Part 14">
        MP4
       </a>
       (with
       <a href="/wiki/H.264/MPEG-4_AVC" title="H.264/MPEG-4 AVC">
        H.264
       </a>
       video) or
       <a href="/wiki/WebM" title="WebM">
        WebM
       </a>
       (with
       <a href="/wiki/VP8" title="VP8">
        VP8
       </a>
       video) formats could play the videos, and not all videos on the site were available.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-69">
        <a href="#cite_note-69">
         [69]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-70">
        <a href="#cite_note-70">
         [70]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       On January 27, 2015, YouTube announced that HTML5 would be the default playback method on
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/HTML5_video_support" title="HTML5 video support">
        supported browsers
       </a>
       . YouTube used to employ
       <a href="/wiki/Adaptive_bitrate_streaming#Adobe_Dynamic_Streaming_for_Flash" title="Adaptive bitrate streaming">
        Adobe Dynamic Streaming for Flash
       </a>
       ,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-71">
        <a href="#cite_note-71">
         [71]
        </a>
       </sup>
       but with the switch to HTML5 video now streams video using
       <a href="/wiki/Dynamic_Adaptive_Streaming_over_HTTP" title="Dynamic Adaptive Streaming over HTTP">
        Dynamic Adaptive Streaming over HTTP
       </a>
       (MPEG-DASH), an adaptive bit-rate HTTP-based streaming solution optimizing the bitrate and quality for the available network.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-72">
        <a href="#cite_note-72">
         [72]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h4>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Uploading">
        Uploading
       </span>
      </h4>
      <p>
       All YouTube users can upload videos up to 15 minutes each in duration. Users who have a good track record of complying with the site's Community Guidelines may be offered the ability to upload videos up to 12 hours in length, as well as live streams, which requires verifying the account, normally through a mobile phone.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-videolength_73-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-videolength-73">
         [73]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-intro_to_live_74-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-intro_to_live-74">
         [74]
        </a>
       </sup>
       When YouTube was launched in 2005, it was possible to upload longer videos, but a ten-minute limit was introduced in March 2006 after YouTube found that the majority of videos exceeding this length were unauthorized uploads of television shows and films.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-75">
        <a href="#cite_note-75">
         [75]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The 10-minute limit was increased to 15 minutes in July 2010.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-76">
        <a href="#cite_note-76">
         [76]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In the past, it was possible to upload videos longer than 12 hours. Videos can be at most 128
       <a href="/wiki/Gigabyte" title="Gigabyte">
        GB
       </a>
       in size.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-videolength_73-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-videolength-73">
         [73]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Video captions are made using
       <a href="/wiki/Speech_recognition" title="Speech recognition">
        speech recognition
       </a>
       technology when uploaded. Such captioning is usually not perfectly accurate, so YouTube provides several options for manually entering the captions for greater accuracy.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-captioning_77-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-captioning-77">
         [77]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       YouTube accepts videos that are uploaded in most
       <a href="/wiki/Digital_container_format" title="Digital container format">
        container formats
       </a>
       , including
       <a href="/wiki/Audio_Video_Interleave" title="Audio Video Interleave">
        AVI
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/MPEG-4_Part_14" title="MPEG-4 Part 14">
        MP4
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/MPEG_program_stream" title="MPEG program stream">
        MPEG-PS
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/QuickTime_File_Format" title="QuickTime File Format">
        QuickTime File Format
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Flash_Video" title="Flash Video">
        FLV
       </a>
       . It supports
       <a href="/wiki/WebM" title="WebM">
        WebM
       </a>
       files and also
       <a href="/wiki/3GP_and_3G2" title="3GP and 3G2">
        3GP
       </a>
       , allowing videos to be uploaded from mobile phones.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-78">
        <a href="#cite_note-78">
         [78]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Videos with
       <a href="/wiki/Progressive_scan" title="Progressive scan">
        progressive scanning
       </a>
       or interlaced scanning can be uploaded, but for the best video quality, YouTube suggests interlaced videos be
       <a href="/wiki/Deinterlacing" title="Deinterlacing">
        deinterlaced
       </a>
       before uploading. All the video formats on YouTube use progressive scanning.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-79">
        <a href="#cite_note-79">
         [79]
        </a>
       </sup>
       YouTube's statistics shows that interlaced videos are still being uploaded to YouTube, and there is no sign of that actually dwindling. YouTube attributes this to uploading of made-for-TV content.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-80">
        <a href="#cite_note-80">
         [80]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h4>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Quality_and_formats">
        Quality and formats
       </span>
      </h4>
      <p>
       YouTube originally offered videos at only one quality level, displayed at a resolution of 320×240
       <a href="/wiki/Pixel" title="Pixel">
        pixels
       </a>
       using the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sorenson_codec" title="Sorenson codec">
        Sorenson Spark
       </a>
       codec (a variant of
       <a href="/wiki/H.263" title="H.263">
        H.263
       </a>
       ),
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-incomplete-h263_81-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-incomplete-h263-81">
         [81]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-flash-video_82-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-flash-video-82">
         [82]
        </a>
       </sup>
       with mono MP3 audio.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-83">
        <a href="#cite_note-83">
         [83]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In June 2007, YouTube added an option to watch videos in
       <a href="/wiki/3GP_and_3G2" title="3GP and 3G2">
        3GP
       </a>
       format on mobile phones.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-84">
        <a href="#cite_note-84">
         [84]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In March 2008, a high-quality mode was added, which increased the resolution to 480×360 pixels.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-85">
        <a href="#cite_note-85">
         [85]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In November 2008,
       <a href="/wiki/720p" title="720p">
        720p
       </a>
       <a href="/wiki/High-definition_video" title="High-definition video">
        HD
       </a>
       support was added. At the time of the 720p launch, the YouTube player was changed from a
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/4:3" title="4:3">
        4:3
       </a>
       <a href="/wiki/Aspect_ratio" title="Aspect ratio">
        aspect ratio
       </a>
       to a
       <a href="/wiki/Widescreen" title="Widescreen">
        widescreen
       </a>
       <a href="/wiki/16:9" title="16:9">
        16:9
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-86">
        <a href="#cite_note-86">
         [86]
        </a>
       </sup>
       With this new feature, YouTube began a switchover to
       <a href="/wiki/H.264/MPEG-4_AVC" title="H.264/MPEG-4 AVC">
        H.264/MPEG-4 AVC
       </a>
       as its default video compression format. In November 2009,
       <a href="/wiki/1080p" title="1080p">
        1080p
       </a>
       HD support was added. In July 2010, YouTube announced that it had launched a range of videos in
       <a href="/wiki/4K_resolution" title="4K resolution">
        4K
       </a>
       format, which allows a resolution of up to 4096×3072 pixels.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-87">
        <a href="#cite_note-87">
         [87]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-88">
        <a href="#cite_note-88">
         [88]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In June 2015, support for
       <a href="/wiki/8K_resolution" title="8K resolution">
        8K resolution
       </a>
       was added, with the videos playing at 7680×4320 pixels.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-89">
        <a href="#cite_note-89">
         [89]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In November 2016, support for
       <a href="/wiki/High-dynamic-range_video" title="High-dynamic-range video">
        HDR video
       </a>
       was added which can be encoded with
       <a href="/wiki/Hybrid_Log-Gamma" title="Hybrid Log-Gamma">
        Hybrid Log-Gamma
       </a>
       (HLG) or
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Perceptual_Quantizer" title="Perceptual Quantizer">
        Perceptual Quantizer
       </a>
       (PQ).
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-90">
        <a href="#cite_note-90">
         [90]
        </a>
       </sup>
       HDR video can be encoded with the
       <a href="/wiki/Rec._2020" title="Rec. 2020">
        Rec. 2020
       </a>
       color space.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-91">
        <a href="#cite_note-91">
         [91]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       In June 2014, YouTube introduced videos playing at 60
       <a href="/wiki/Frame_rate" title="Frame rate">
        frames per second
       </a>
       , in order to reproduce video games with a frame rate comparable to high-end
       <a href="/wiki/Video_card" title="Video card">
        graphics cards
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-92">
        <a href="#cite_note-92">
         [92]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-93">
        <a href="#cite_note-93">
         [93]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The videos play back at a resolution of 720p or higher.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-94">
        <a href="#cite_note-94">
         [94]
        </a>
       </sup>
       YouTube videos are available in a range of quality levels. The former names of standard quality (SQ), high quality (HQ), and high definition (HD) have been replaced by numerical values representing the vertical resolution of the video. The default video stream is encoded in the
       <a href="/wiki/VP9" title="VP9">
        VP9
       </a>
       format with stereo
       <a href="/wiki/Opus_(audio_format)" title="Opus (audio format)">
        Opus
       </a>
       audio; if VP9/WebM is not supported in the browser/device or the browser's user agent reports
       <a href="/wiki/Windows_XP" title="Windows XP">
        Windows XP
       </a>
       , then
       <a href="/wiki/H.264/MPEG-4_AVC" title="H.264/MPEG-4 AVC">
        H.264/MPEG-4 AVC
       </a>
       video with stereo
       <a href="/wiki/Advanced_Audio_Coding" title="Advanced Audio Coding">
        AAC
       </a>
       audio is used instead.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-95">
        <a href="#cite_note-95">
         [95]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h4>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Live_streaming">
        Live streaming
       </span>
      </h4>
      <p>
       YouTube carried out early experiments with
       <a href="/wiki/Live_streaming" title="Live streaming">
        live streaming
       </a>
       , including a concert by
       <a href="/wiki/U2" title="U2">
        U2
       </a>
       in 2009, and a question-and-answer session with US President
       <a href="/wiki/Barack_Obama" title="Barack Obama">
        Barack Obama
       </a>
       in February 2010.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CNN_2010_96-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-CNN_2010-96">
         [96]
        </a>
       </sup>
       These tests had relied on technology from 3rd-party partners, but in September 2010, YouTube began testing its own live streaming infrastructure.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-BBC_2010_97-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-BBC_2010-97">
         [97]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In April 2011, YouTube announced the rollout of
       <i>
        YouTube Live
       </i>
       , with a portal page at the URL "www.youtube.com/live". The creation of live streams was initially limited to select partners.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-YT_Blog_2011_98-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-YT_Blog_2011-98">
         [98]
        </a>
       </sup>
       It was used for real-time broadcasting of events such as the 2012 Olympics in London.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-99">
        <a href="#cite_note-99">
         [99]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In October 2012, more than 8 million people watched
       <a href="/wiki/Felix_Baumgartner" title="Felix Baumgartner">
        Felix Baumgartner
       </a>
       's
       <a href="/wiki/Red_Bull_Stratos" title="Red Bull Stratos">
        jump from the edge of space
       </a>
       as a live stream on YouTube.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-100">
        <a href="#cite_note-100">
         [100]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       In May 2013, creation of live streams was opened to verified users with at least 1,000 subscribers; in August of that year the number was reduced to 100 subscribers,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Verge_2013_101-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Verge_2013-101">
         [101]
        </a>
       </sup>
       and in December the limit was removed.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-MacNN_2013_102-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-MacNN_2013-102">
         [102]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In February 2017, a live streaming feature was introduced to the official YouTube mobile app. Live streaming via mobile was initially restricted to users with at least 10,000 subscribers,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ars_Technica_2017-02-08_103-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Ars_Technica_2017-02-08-103">
         [103]
        </a>
       </sup>
       but as of mid-2017 it has been reduced to 100 subscribers.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-create_live_104-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-create_live-104">
         [104]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Live streams can be up to 4K resolution at 60 fps, and also support 360° video.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Verge_2016_105-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Verge_2016-105">
         [105]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h4>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="3D_videos">
        3D videos
       </span>
      </h4>
      <p>
       In a video posted on July 21, 2009,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-106">
        <a href="#cite_note-106">
         [106]
        </a>
       </sup>
       YouTube software engineer
       <a href="/wiki/Peter_Bradshaw" title="Peter Bradshaw">
        Peter Bradshaw
       </a>
       announced that YouTube users can now upload
       <a href="/wiki/3D_film" title="3D film">
        3D videos
       </a>
       . The videos can be viewed in several different ways, including the common
       <a href="/wiki/Anaglyph_3D" title="Anaglyph 3D">
        anaglyph
       </a>
       (cyan/red lens) method which utilizes glasses worn by the viewer to achieve the 3D effect.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-107">
        <a href="#cite_note-107">
         [107]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-108">
        <a href="#cite_note-108">
         [108]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-109">
        <a href="#cite_note-109">
         [109]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The YouTube Flash player can display stereoscopic content interleaved in rows, columns or a checkerboard pattern, side-by-side or anaglyph using a red/cyan, green/magenta or blue/yellow combination. In May 2011, an
       <a href="/wiki/HTML5" title="HTML5">
        HTML5
       </a>
       version of the YouTube player began supporting side-by-side 3D footage that is compatible with
       <a href="/wiki/Nvidia_3D_Vision" title="Nvidia 3D Vision">
        Nvidia 3D Vision
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-110">
        <a href="#cite_note-110">
         [110]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h4>
       <span id="360.C2.B0_videos">
       </span>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="360°_videos">
        360° videos
       </span>
      </h4>
      <p>
       In January 2015, Google announced that
       <a href="/wiki/360-degree_video" title="360-degree video">
        360° videos
       </a>
       would be natively supported on YouTube. On March 13, 2015, YouTube enabled 360° videos which can be viewed from
       <a href="/wiki/Google_Cardboard" title="Google Cardboard">
        Google Cardboard
       </a>
       , a
       <a href="/wiki/Virtual_reality" title="Virtual reality">
        virtual reality
       </a>
       system. YouTube 360 can also be viewed from all other
       <a href="/wiki/Virtual_reality" title="Virtual reality">
        virtual reality
       </a>
       headsets.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-111">
        <a href="#cite_note-111">
         [111]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Live streaming of 360° video at up to 4K resolution is also supported.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Verge_2016_105-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-Verge_2016-105">
         [105]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="User_features">
        User features
       </span>
      </h3>
      <h4>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Community">
        Community
       </span>
      </h4>
      <p>
       On September 13, 2016, YouTube launched a
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Public_beta" title="Public beta">
        public beta
       </a>
       of Community, a
       <a href="/wiki/Social_media" title="Social media">
        social media
       </a>
       -based feature that allows users to post text, images (including
       <a href="/wiki/GIF" title="GIF">
        GIFs
       </a>
       ), live videos and others in a separate "Community" tab on their channel.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-112">
        <a href="#cite_note-112">
         [112]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Prior to the release, several creators had been consulted to suggest tools Community could incorporate that they would find useful; these YouTubers included
       <a href="/wiki/Vlogbrothers" title="Vlogbrothers">
        Vlogbrothers
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/AsapScience" title="AsapScience">
        AsapScience
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Lilly_Singh" title="Lilly Singh">
        Lilly Singh
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/MatPat" title="MatPat">
        The Game Theorists
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Karmin" title="Karmin">
        Karmin
       </a>
       ,
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Barely_Productions" title="Barely Productions">
        The Key of Awesome
       </a>
       , The Kloons,
       <a href="/wiki/Peter_Hollens" title="Peter Hollens">
        Peter Hollens
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Rosianna_Halse_Rojas" title="Rosianna Halse Rojas">
        Rosianna Halse Rojas
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Sam_Tsui" title="Sam Tsui">
        Sam Tsui
       </a>
       , Threadbanger and Vsauce3.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-113">
        <a href="#cite_note-113">
         [113]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Content_accessibility">
        Content accessibility
       </span>
      </h3>
      <p>
       YouTube offers users the ability to view its videos on web pages outside their website. Each YouTube video is accompanied by a piece of
       <a href="/wiki/HTML" title="HTML">
        HTML
       </a>
       that can be used to embed it on any page on the Web.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-114">
        <a href="#cite_note-114">
         [114]
        </a>
       </sup>
       This functionality is often used to embed YouTube videos in social networking pages and blogs. Users wishing to post a video discussing, inspired by or related to another user's video are able to make a "video response". On August 27, 2013, YouTube announced that it would remove video responses for being an underused feature.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-115">
        <a href="#cite_note-115">
         [115]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Embedding, rating, commenting and response posting can be disabled by the video owner.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-116">
        <a href="#cite_note-116">
         [116]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       YouTube does not usually offer a download link for its videos, and intends for them to be viewed through its website interface.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-117">
        <a href="#cite_note-117">
         [117]
        </a>
       </sup>
       A small number of videos, can be downloaded as
       <a href="/wiki/MPEG-4_Part_14" title="MPEG-4 Part 14">
        MP4
       </a>
       files.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-118">
        <a href="#cite_note-118">
         [118]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Numerous third-party web sites, applications and browser
       <a href="/wiki/Plug-in_(computing)" title="Plug-in (computing)">
        plug-ins
       </a>
       allow users to download YouTube videos.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-119">
        <a href="#cite_note-119">
         [119]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In February 2009, YouTube announced a test service, allowing some partners to offer video downloads for free or for a fee paid through
       <a href="/wiki/Google_Checkout" title="Google Checkout">
        Google Checkout
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-120">
        <a href="#cite_note-120">
         [120]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In June 2012, Google sent
       <a href="/wiki/Cease_and_desist" title="Cease and desist">
        cease and desist
       </a>
       letters threatening legal action against several websites offering online download and conversion of YouTube videos.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-121">
        <a href="#cite_note-121">
         [121]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In response,
       <a href="/wiki/Zamzar" title="Zamzar">
        Zamzar
       </a>
       removed the ability to download YouTube videos from its site.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-122">
        <a href="#cite_note-122">
         [122]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Users retain copyright of their own work, but have the option to grant certain usage rights under any
       <a href="/wiki/Public_copyright_license" title="Public copyright license">
        public copyright license
       </a>
       they choose. Since July 2012, it has been possible to select a
       <a href="/wiki/Creative_Commons" title="Creative Commons">
        Creative Commons
       </a>
       license as the default, allowing other users to reuse and remix the material.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-123">
        <a href="#cite_note-123">
         [123]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h4>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Platforms">
        Platforms
       </span>
      </h4>
      <p>
       Most modern
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Smartphones" title="Smartphones">
        smartphones
       </a>
       are capable of accessing YouTube videos, either within an application or through an optimized website. YouTube Mobile was launched in June 2007, using
       <a href="/wiki/Real_Time_Streaming_Protocol" title="Real Time Streaming Protocol">
        RTSP
       </a>
       streaming for the video.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-124">
        <a href="#cite_note-124">
         [124]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Not all of YouTube's videos are available on the mobile version of the site.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-125">
        <a href="#cite_note-125">
         [125]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Since June 2007, YouTube's videos have been available for viewing on a range of
       <a href="/wiki/Apple_Inc." title="Apple Inc.">
        Apple
       </a>
       products. This required YouTube's content to be transcoded into Apple's preferred video standard,
       <a href="/wiki/H.264/MPEG-4_AVC" title="H.264/MPEG-4 AVC">
        H.264
       </a>
       , a process that took several months. YouTube videos can be viewed on devices including
       <a href="/wiki/Apple_TV" title="Apple TV">
        Apple TV
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/IPod_Touch" title="IPod Touch">
        iPod Touch
       </a>
       and the
       <a href="/wiki/IPhone" title="IPhone">
        iPhone
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-126">
        <a href="#cite_note-126">
         [126]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In July 2010, the mobile version of the site was relaunched based on
       <a href="/wiki/HTML5" title="HTML5">
        HTML5
       </a>
       , avoiding the need to use Adobe Flash Player and optimized for use with touch screen controls.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-127">
        <a href="#cite_note-127">
         [127]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The mobile version is also available as an app for the Android platform.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-128">
        <a href="#cite_note-128">
         [128]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-129">
        <a href="#cite_note-129">
         [129]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In September 2012, YouTube launched its first app for the iPhone, following the decision to drop YouTube as one of the preloaded apps in the iPhone 5 and iOS 6 operating system.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-130">
        <a href="#cite_note-130">
         [130]
        </a>
       </sup>
       According to
       <a href="/wiki/GlobalWebIndex" title="GlobalWebIndex">
        GlobalWebIndex
       </a>
       , YouTube was used by 35% of smartphone users between April and June 2013, making it the third-most used app.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-131">
        <a href="#cite_note-131">
         [131]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       A
       <a href="/wiki/TiVo" title="TiVo">
        TiVo
       </a>
       service update in July 2008 allowed the system to search and play YouTube videos.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-132">
        <a href="#cite_note-132">
         [132]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In January 2009, YouTube launched "YouTube for TV", a version of the website tailored for set-top boxes and other TV-based media devices with web browsers, initially allowing its videos to be viewed on the
       <a href="/wiki/PlayStation_3" title="PlayStation 3">
        PlayStation 3
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Wii" title="Wii">
        Wii
       </a>
       <a href="/wiki/Video_game_console" title="Video game console">
        video game consoles
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-133">
        <a href="#cite_note-133">
         [133]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-134">
        <a href="#cite_note-134">
         [134]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In June 2009, YouTube XL was introduced, which has a simplified interface designed for viewing on a standard television screen.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-135">
        <a href="#cite_note-135">
         [135]
        </a>
       </sup>
       YouTube is also available as an app on
       <a href="/wiki/Xbox_Live" title="Xbox Live">
        Xbox Live
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-136">
        <a href="#cite_note-136">
         [136]
        </a>
       </sup>
       On November 15, 2012, Google launched an official app for the Wii, allowing users to watch YouTube videos from the Wii channel.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-137">
        <a href="#cite_note-137">
         [137]
        </a>
       </sup>
       An app is also available for
       <a href="/wiki/Wii_U" title="Wii U">
        Wii U
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Nintendo_3DS" title="Nintendo 3DS">
        Nintendo 3DS
       </a>
       , and videos can be viewed on the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Internet_Browser_(Wii_U)" title="Internet Browser (Wii U)">
        Wii U Internet Browser
       </a>
       using HTML5.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-138">
        <a href="#cite_note-138">
         [138]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Google made YouTube available on the
       <a href="/wiki/Roku" title="Roku">
        Roku
       </a>
       player on December 17, 2013,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-139">
        <a href="#cite_note-139">
         [139]
        </a>
       </sup>
       and, in October 2014, the Sony
       <a href="/wiki/PlayStation_4" title="PlayStation 4">
        PlayStation 4
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-140">
        <a href="#cite_note-140">
         [140]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Localization">
        Localization
       </span>
      </h3>
      <p>
       On June 19, 2007, Google CEO
       <a href="/wiki/Eric_Schmidt" title="Eric Schmidt">
        Eric Schmidt
       </a>
       was in Paris to launch the new
       <a href="/wiki/Internationalization_and_localization" title="Internationalization and localization">
        localization
       </a>
       system.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-local_141-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-local-141">
         [141]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The interface of the website is available with localized versions in 89 countries, one territory (Hong Kong) and a worldwide version.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-142">
        <a href="#cite_note-142">
         [142]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <table class="wikitable mw-collapsible mw-collapsed" style="margin: 1em auto;" width="70%">
       <caption>
        <b>
         Countries with YouTube localization
        </b>
       </caption>
       <tr>
        <td colspan="4" style="text-align: center;">
         <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:YouTube_Localisation.svg">
          <img alt="YouTube Localisation.svg" data-file-height="1314" data-file-width="2560" height="308" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5a/YouTube_Localisation.svg/600px-YouTube_Localisation.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5a/YouTube_Localisation.svg/900px-YouTube_Localisation.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5a/YouTube_Localisation.svg/1200px-YouTube_Localisation.svg.png 2x" width="600"/>
         </a>
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <th>
         Country
        </th>

        </th>

       </tr>

         <a href="/wiki/United_States" title="United States">
          USA
         </a>
         (and worldwide launch)
        </td>

         </span>
         <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-local_141-1">
          <a href="#cite_note-local-141">
           [141]
          </a>
         </sup>
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr>

          German
         </a>
        </td>
        <td>
         ?, 2014
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr>

          <img alt="" class="thumbborder" data-file-height="600" data-file-width="900" height="15" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/21/Flag_of_Vietnam.svg/23px-Flag_of_Vietnam.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/21/Flag_of_Vietnam.svg/35px-Flag_of_Vietnam.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/21/Flag_of_Vietnam.svg/45px-Flag_of_Vietnam.svg.png 2x" width="23"/>

         </span>

          <a href="#cite_note-himalayan-188">
           [188]
          </a>
         </sup>

       </tr>
       <tr>
        <td>
         <span class="flagicon">
          <img alt="" class="thumbborder" data-file-height="274" data-file-width="411" height="15" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f6/Flag_of_Iraq.svg/23px-Flag_of_Iraq.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f6/Flag_of_Iraq.svg/35px-Flag_of_Iraq.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f6/Flag_of_Iraq.svg/45px-Flag_of_Iraq.svg.png 2x" width="23"/>
         </span>

         ?, 2016
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <td>
         <span class="flagicon">
          <img alt="" class="thumbborder" data-file-height="300" data-file-width="600" height="12" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0a/Flag_of_Jamaica.svg/23px-Flag_of_Jamaica.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0a/Flag_of_Jamaica.svg/35px-Flag_of_Jamaica.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0a/Flag_of_Jamaica.svg/46px-Flag_of_Jamaica.svg.png 2x" width="23"/>
         </span>
         <a href="/wiki/Jamaica" title="Jamaica">
          Jamaica
         </a>
        </td>
        <td>
         <a href="/wiki/Jamaican_English" title="Jamaican English">
          English
         </a>
        </td>
        <td>
         ?, 2016
        </td>
       </tr>
      </table>
      <p>
       The YouTube interface suggests which local version should be chosen on the basis of the IP address of the user. In some cases, the message "This video is not available in your country" may appear because of copyright restrictions or inappropriate content.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-190">
        <a href="#cite_note-190">
         [190]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The interface of the YouTube website is available in 76 language versions, including Amharic, Albanian, Armenian, Bengali, Burmese, Khmer, Kyrgyz, Laotian, Mongolian, Persian and Uzbek, which do not have local channel versions.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-languages_191-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-languages-191">
         [191]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Access to YouTube was blocked in
       <a href="/wiki/Turkey" title="Turkey">
        Turkey
       </a>
       between 2008 and 2010, following controversy over the posting of videos deemed insulting to
       <a href="/wiki/Mustafa_Kemal_Atat%C3%BCrk" title="Mustafa Kemal Atatürk">
        Mustafa Kemal Atatürk
       </a>
       and some material offensive to Muslims.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-192">
        <a href="#cite_note-192">
         [192]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-193">
        <a href="#cite_note-193">
         [193]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In October 2012, a local version of YouTube was launched in Turkey, with the domain
       <code>
        youtube.com.tr
       </code>
       . The local version is subject to the content regulations found in Turkish law.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-194">
        <a href="#cite_note-194">
         [194]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In March 2009, a dispute between YouTube and the British royalty collection agency
       <a href="/wiki/PRS_for_Music" title="PRS for Music">
        PRS for Music
       </a>
       led to premium music videos being blocked for YouTube users in the United Kingdom. The removal of videos posted by the major record companies occurred after failure to reach agreement on a licensing deal. The dispute was resolved in September 2009.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-195">
        <a href="#cite_note-195">
         [195]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In April 2009, a similar dispute led to the removal of premium music videos for users in Germany.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-196">
        <a href="#cite_note-196">
         [196]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="YouTube_Red">
        YouTube Red
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/YouTube_Red" title="YouTube Red">
        YouTube Red
       </a>
      </div>
      <p>
       YouTube Red is YouTube's premium subscription service. It offers advertising-free streaming, access to exclusive content, background and offline video playback on mobile devices, and access to the
       <a href="/wiki/Google_Play_Music" title="Google Play Music">
        Google Play Music
       </a>
       "All Access" service.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-197">
        <a href="#cite_note-197">
         [197]
        </a>
       </sup>
       YouTube Red was originally announced on November 12, 2014, as "Music Key", a
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Comparison_of_on-demand_streaming_music_services" title="Comparison of on-demand streaming music services">
        subscription music streaming
       </a>
       service, and was intended to integrate with and replace the existing Google Play Music "All Access" service.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-198">
        <a href="#cite_note-198">
         [198]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-199">
        <a href="#cite_note-199">
         [199]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Variety_Music_Key_200-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Variety_Music_Key-200">
         [200]
        </a>
       </sup>
       On October 28, 2015, the service was re-launched as YouTube Red, offering ad-free streaming of all videos, as well as access to exclusive original content.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-201">
        <a href="#cite_note-201">
         [201]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-202">
        <a href="#cite_note-202">
         [202]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-203">
        <a href="#cite_note-203">
         [203]
        </a>
       </sup>
       As of November 2016
       <sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;">
        <a class="external text" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=YouTube&amp;action=edit">
         [update]
        </a>
       </sup>
       , the service has 1.5 million subscribers, with a further million on a free-trial basis.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-204">
        <a href="#cite_note-204">
         [204]
        </a>
       </sup>
       As of June 2017
       <sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;">
        <a class="external text" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=YouTube&amp;action=edit">
         [update]
        </a>
       </sup>
       , the first season of YouTube Red Originals had gotten 250 million views in total.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-205">
        <a href="#cite_note-205">
         [205]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       In May 2014, before Music Key service was launched, the independent music trade organization Worldwide Independent Network alleged that YouTube was using non-negotiable contracts with independent labels that were "undervalued" in comparison to other streaming services, and that YouTube would block all music content from labels who do not reach a deal to be included on the paid service. In a statement to the
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/Financial_Times" title="Financial Times">
         Financial Times
        </a>
       </i>
       in June 2014, Robert Kyncl confirmed that YouTube would block the content of labels who do not negotiate deals to be included in the paid service "to ensure that all content on the platform is governed by its new contractual terms." Stating that 90% of labels had reached deals, he went on to say that "while we wish that we had [a] 100% success rate, we understand that is not likely an achievable goal and therefore it is our responsibility to our users and the industry to launch the enhanced music experience."
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-206">
        <a href="#cite_note-206">
         [206]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-guardian-musicpass_207-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-guardian-musicpass-207">
         [207]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-guardian-stall_208-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-guardian-stall-208">
         [208]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-guardian-indieblock_209-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-guardian-indieblock-209">
         [209]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The
       <i>
        Financial Times
       </i>
       later reported that YouTube had reached an aggregate deal with
       <a href="/wiki/Merlin_Network" title="Merlin Network">
        Merlin Network
       </a>
       —a trade group representing over 20,000 independent labels, for their inclusion in the service. However, YouTube itself has not confirmed the deal.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Variety_Music_Key_200-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-Variety_Music_Key-200">
         [200]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       On September 28, 2016, YouTube named
       <a href="/wiki/Lyor_Cohen" title="Lyor Cohen">
        Lyor Cohen
       </a>
       , the co-founder of
       <a href="/wiki/300_Entertainment" title="300 Entertainment">
        300 Entertainment
       </a>
       and former
       <a href="/wiki/Warner_Music_Group" title="Warner Music Group">
        Warner Music Group
       </a>
       executive, the Global Head of Music.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-210">
        <a href="#cite_note-210">
         [210]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In early 2018, Cohen began hinting at the possible launch of YouTube's new subscription music streaming service, a platform that would compete with other services such as
       <a href="/wiki/Spotify" title="Spotify">
        Spotify
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Apple_Music" title="Apple Music">
        Apple Music
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-211">
        <a href="#cite_note-211">
         [211]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The service is expected to be launched in March 2018.
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="YouTube_TV">
        YouTube TV
       </span>
      </h3>
      <p>
       On February 28, 2017, in a press announcement held at YouTube Space Los Angeles, YouTube announced the launch of YouTube TV, an
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Over-the-top_content" title="Over-the-top content">
        over-the-top
       </a>
       <a href="/wiki/Multichannel_video_programming_distributor" title="Multichannel video programming distributor">
        MVPD
       </a>
       -style subscription service that would be available for United States customers at a price of US$35 per month. Initially launching in five major markets (
       <a href="/wiki/New_York_City" title="New York City">
        New York City
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Los_Angeles" title="Los Angeles">
        Los Angeles
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Chicago" title="Chicago">
        Chicago
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Philadelphia" title="Philadelphia">
        Philadelphia
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/San_Francisco" title="San Francisco">
        San Francisco
       </a>
       ) on April 5, 2017,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-212">
        <a href="#cite_note-212">
         [212]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-213">
        <a href="#cite_note-213">
         [213]
        </a>
       </sup>
       the service offers live streams of programming from the five major broadcast networks (
       <a href="/wiki/American_Broadcasting_Company" title="American Broadcasting Company">
        ABC
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/CBS" title="CBS">
        CBS
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/The_CW" title="The CW">
        The CW
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Fox_Broadcasting_Company" title="Fox Broadcasting Company">
        Fox Broadcasting Company
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/NBC" title="NBC">
        NBC
       </a>
       ), as well as approximately 40 cable channels owned by the corporate parents of those networks,
       <a href="/wiki/The_Walt_Disney_Company" title="The Walt Disney Company">
        The Walt Disney Company
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/CBS_Corporation" title="CBS Corporation">
        CBS Corporation
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/21st_Century_Fox" title="21st Century Fox">
        21st Century Fox
       </a>
       , and
       <a href="/wiki/NBCUniversal" title="NBCUniversal">
        NBCUniversal
       </a>
       (including among others
       <a href="/wiki/Bravo_(U.S._TV_network)" title="Bravo (U.S. TV network)">
        Bravo
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/USA_Network" title="USA Network">
        USA Network
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Syfy" title="Syfy">
        Syfy
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Disney_Channel" title="Disney Channel">
        Disney Channel
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/E!" title="E!">
        E!
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Fox_Sports_1" title="Fox Sports 1">
        Fox Sports 1
       </a>
       ,
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Freeform_(TV_network)" title="Freeform (TV network)">
        Freeform
       </a>
       ,
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/FX_(TV_network)" title="FX (TV network)">
        FX
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/ESPN" title="ESPN">
        ESPN
       </a>
       ). Subscribers can also receive
       <a href="/wiki/Showtime_(TV_network)" title="Showtime (TV network)">
        Showtime
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Fox_Soccer_Plus" title="Fox Soccer Plus">
        Fox Soccer Plus
       </a>
       as optional add-ons for an extra fee, and can access
       <a href="/wiki/YouTube_Red" title="YouTube Red">
        YouTube Red
       </a>
       original content (YouTube TV does not include a YouTube Red subscription).
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-214">
        <a href="#cite_note-214">
         [214]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-215">
        <a href="#cite_note-215">
         [215]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       During the
       <a href="/wiki/2017_World_Series" title="2017 World Series">
        2017 World Series
       </a>
       (in which it was the presenting sponsor), YouTube TV ads were placed behind the home plate. The trademarked red play button logo appeared at the center of the screen, mimicking YouTube's interface.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-216">
        <a href="#cite_note-216">
         [216]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="YouTube_Go">
        YouTube Go
       </span>
      </h3>
      <p>
       YouTube Go is an
       <a href="/wiki/Android_(operating_system)" title="Android (operating system)">
        Android
       </a>
       app aimed at making YouTube easier to access on mobile devices in
       <a href="/wiki/Developing_country" title="Developing country">
        developing countries
       </a>
       . It allows videos to be downloaded and shared with other users without incurring additional data charges. Following a trial in
       <a href="/wiki/India" title="India">
        India
       </a>
       in 2017, YouTube Go was launched in over 130 countries in February 2018.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:0_217-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-:0-217">
         [217]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-218">
