        <a href="#cite_note-218">
         [218]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="April_Fools">
        April Fools
       </span>
      </h3>
      <p>
       YouTube featured an
       <a href="/wiki/April_Fools%27_Day" title="April Fools' Day">
        April Fools
       </a>
       prank on the site on April 1 of every year. In 2008, all links to videos on the main page were redirected to
       <a href="/wiki/Rick_Astley" title="Rick Astley">
        Rick Astley
       </a>
       's music video "
       <a href="/wiki/Never_Gonna_Give_You_Up" title="Never Gonna Give You Up">
        Never Gonna Give You Up
       </a>
       ", a prank known as "
       <a href="/wiki/Rickrolling" title="Rickrolling">
        rickrolling
       </a>
       ".
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-219">
        <a href="#cite_note-219">
         [219]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-220">
        <a href="#cite_note-220">
         [220]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The next year, when clicking on a video on the main page, the whole page turned upside down, which YouTube claimed was a "new layout".
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-221">
        <a href="#cite_note-221">
         [221]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In 2010, YouTube temporarily released a "TEXTp" mode which transformed colors in videos to random uppercase letters "in order to reduce bandwidth costs by $1 per second."
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-222">
        <a href="#cite_note-222">
         [222]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The next year, the site celebrated its "100th anniversary" with a range of sepia-toned silent, early 1900s-style films, including a parody of
       <a href="/wiki/Keyboard_Cat" title="Keyboard Cat">
        Keyboard Cat
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-223">
        <a href="#cite_note-223">
         [223]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In 2012, clicking on the image of a DVD next to the site logo led to a video about a purported option to order every YouTube video for home delivery on DVD.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-224">
        <a href="#cite_note-224">
         [224]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In 2013, YouTube teamed up with satirical newspaper company
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/The_Onion" title="The Onion">
         The Onion
        </a>
       </i>
       to claim that the video sharing website was launched as a contest which had finally come to an end, and would announce a winner of the contest when the site went back up in 2023.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-225">
        <a href="#cite_note-225">
         [225]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In 2014, YouTube announced that it was responsible for the creation of all viral video trends, and revealed previews of upcoming internet memes, such as "Clocking", "Kissing Dad", and "Glub Glub Water Dance".
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-226">
        <a href="#cite_note-226">
         [226]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The next year, YouTube added a music button to the video bar that played samples from "
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sandstorm_(Darude_composition)" title="Sandstorm (Darude composition)">
        Sandstorm
       </a>
       " by
       <a href="/wiki/Darude" title="Darude">
        Darude
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-227">
        <a href="#cite_note-227">
         [227]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In 2016, YouTube introduced an option to watch every video on the platform in 360-degree mode with
       <a href="/wiki/Snoop_Dogg" title="Snoop Dogg">
        Snoop Dogg
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-228">
        <a href="#cite_note-228">
         [228]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h2>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Social_impact">
        Social impact
       </span>
      </h2>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/Social_impact_of_YouTube" title="Social impact of YouTube">
        Social impact of YouTube
       </a>
      </div>
      <p>
       Both private individuals
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Reuters20070225_229-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Reuters20070225-229">
         [229]
        </a>
       </sup>
       and large production companies
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-WiredUK20131127_230-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-WiredUK20131127-230">
         [230]
        </a>
       </sup>
       have used YouTube to grow audiences. Independent content creators have built grassroots followings numbering in the thousands at very little cost or effort, while mass retail and radio promotion proved problematic.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Reuters20070225_229-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-Reuters20070225-229">
         [229]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Concurrently,
       <a href="/wiki/Old_media" title="Old media">
        old media
       </a>
       celebrities moved into the website at the invitation of a YouTube management that witnessed early content creators accruing substantial followings, and perceived audience sizes potentially larger than that attainable by television.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-WiredUK20131127_230-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-WiredUK20131127-230">
         [230]
        </a>
       </sup>
       While YouTube's revenue-sharing "Partner Program" made it possible to earn a substantial living as a video producer—its top five hundred partners each earning more than $100,000 annually
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NewYorker20120116_231-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-NewYorker20120116-231">
         [231]
        </a>
       </sup>
       and its ten highest-earning channels grossing from $2.5 million to $12 million
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Forbes20151113_232-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Forbes20151113-232">
         [232]
        </a>
       </sup>
       —in 2012
       <a href="/wiki/Complete_Music_Update" title="Complete Music Update">
        CMU
       </a>
       business editor characterized YouTube as "a free-to-use... promotional platform for the music labels".
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-BBC20121221_233-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-BBC20121221-233">
         [233]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In 2013
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/Forbes" title="Forbes">
         Forbes
        </a>
       </i>
       <span class="nowrap" style="padding-left:0.1em;">
        '
       </span>
       Katheryn Thayer asserted that digital-era artists' work must not only be of high quality, but must elicit reactions on the YouTube platform and social media.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Forbes20131029_234-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Forbes20131029-234">
         [234]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Videos of the 2.5% of artists categorized as "mega", "mainstream" and "mid-sized" received 90.3% of the relevant views on YouTube and Vevo in that year.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NextBigSound2013YearInRewind_235-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-NextBigSound2013YearInRewind-235">
         [235]
        </a>
       </sup>
       By early 2013
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/Billboard_(magazine)" title="Billboard (magazine)">
         Billboard
        </a>
       </i>
       had announced that it was factoring YouTube streaming data into calculation of the
       <a href="/wiki/Billboard_Hot_100" title="Billboard Hot 100">
        <i>
         Billboard
        </i>
        Hot 100
       </a>
       and related genre charts.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Billboard20130220_236-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Billboard20130220-236">
         [236]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Jordan_Hoffner_at_the_68th_Annual_Peabody_Awards_for_YouTube.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="5616" data-file-width="3744" height="255" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/93/Jordan_Hoffner_at_the_68th_Annual_Peabody_Awards_for_YouTube.jpg/170px-Jordan_Hoffner_at_the_68th_Annual_Peabody_Awards_for_YouTube.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/93/Jordan_Hoffner_at_the_68th_Annual_Peabody_Awards_for_YouTube.jpg/255px-Jordan_Hoffner_at_the_68th_Annual_Peabody_Awards_for_YouTube.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/93/Jordan_Hoffner_at_the_68th_Annual_Peabody_Awards_for_YouTube.jpg/340px-Jordan_Hoffner_at_the_68th_Annual_Peabody_Awards_for_YouTube.jpg 2x" width="170"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Jordan_Hoffner_at_the_68th_Annual_Peabody_Awards_for_YouTube.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         Jordan Hoffner at the 68th Annual
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Peabody_Awards" title="Peabody Awards">
          Peabody Awards
         </a>
         accepting for YouTube
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       Observing that face-to-face communication of the type that online videos convey has been "fine-tuned by millions of years of evolution",
       <a href="/wiki/TED_(conference)" title="TED (conference)">
        TED
       </a>
       curator
       <a href="/wiki/Chris_Anderson_(entrepreneur)" title="Chris Anderson (entrepreneur)">
        Chris Anderson
       </a>
       referred to several YouTube contributors and asserted that "what
       <a href="/wiki/Johannes_Gutenberg" title="Johannes Gutenberg">
        Gutenberg
       </a>
       did for writing, online video can now do for face-to-face communication".
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-TED201007Anderson_237-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-TED201007Anderson-237">
         [237]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Anderson asserted that it's not far-fetched to say that online video will dramatically accelerate scientific advance, and that video contributors may be about to launch "the biggest learning cycle in human history."
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-TED201007Anderson_237-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-TED201007Anderson-237">
         [237]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In education, for example, the
       <a href="/wiki/Khan_Academy" title="Khan Academy">
        Khan Academy
       </a>
       grew from YouTube video tutoring sessions for founder Salman Khan's cousin into what
       <i>
        Forbes
       </i>
       <span class="nowrap" style="padding-left:0.1em;">
        '
       </span>
       Michael Noer called "the largest school in the world", with technology poised to
       <a href="/wiki/Disruptive_innovation" title="Disruptive innovation">
        disrupt
       </a>
       how people learn.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Forbes20121102_238-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Forbes20121102-238">
         [238]
        </a>
       </sup>
       YouTube was awarded a 2008
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/George_Foster_Peabody_Award" title="George Foster Peabody Award">
        George Foster Peabody Award
       </a>
       ,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-239">
        <a href="#cite_note-239">
         [239]
        </a>
       </sup>
       the website being described as a
       <a href="/wiki/Speakers%27_Corner" title="Speakers' Corner">
        Speakers' Corner
       </a>
       that "both embodies and promotes democracy."
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-240">
        <a href="#cite_note-240">
         [240]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <i>
        The Washington Post
       </i>
       reported that a disproportionate share of YouTube's most subscribed channels feature minorities, contrasting with mainstream television in which the stars are largely white.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-241">
        <a href="#cite_note-241">
         [241]
        </a>
       </sup>
       A
       <a href="/wiki/Pew_Research_Center" title="Pew Research Center">
        Pew Research Center
       </a>
       study reported the development of "visual journalism", in which citizen eyewitnesses and established news organizations share in content creation.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-PEW20120716_242-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-PEW20120716-242">
         [242]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The study also concluded that YouTube was becoming an important platform by which people acquire news.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-PewYTnews20120716_243-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-PewYTnews20120716-243">
         [243]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       YouTube has enabled people to more directly engage with government, such as in the
       <a href="/wiki/CNN/YouTube_presidential_debates" title="CNN/YouTube presidential debates">
        CNN/YouTube presidential debates
       </a>
       (2007) in which ordinary people submitted questions to U.S. presidential candidates via YouTube video, with a
       <a href="/wiki/TechPresident" title="TechPresident">
        techPresident
       </a>
       co-founder saying that Internet video was changing the political landscape.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-244">
        <a href="#cite_note-244">
         [244]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Describing the
       <a href="/wiki/Arab_Spring" title="Arab Spring">
        Arab Spring
       </a>
       (2010– ), sociologist
       <a href="/wiki/Philip_N._Howard" title="Philip N. Howard">
        Philip N. Howard
       </a>
       quoted an activist's succinct description that organizing the political unrest involved using "Facebook to schedule the protests, Twitter to coordinate, and YouTube to tell the world."
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-PacificStd20110223_245-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-PacificStd20110223-245">
         [245]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In 2012, more than a third of the U.S. Senate introduced a resolution condemning
       <a href="/wiki/Joseph_Kony" title="Joseph Kony">
        Joseph Kony
       </a>
       16 days after the "
       <a href="/wiki/Kony_2012" title="Kony 2012">
        Kony 2012
       </a>
       " video was posted to YouTube, with resolution co-sponsor Senator Lindsey Graham remarking that the video "will do more to lead to (Kony's) demise than all other action combined."
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Politico20120322_246-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Politico20120322-246">
         [246]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:252px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:ObamaYouTubers307.png">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="504" data-file-width="847" height="149" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/90/ObamaYouTubers307.png/250px-ObamaYouTubers307.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/90/ObamaYouTubers307.png/375px-ObamaYouTubers307.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/90/ObamaYouTubers307.png/500px-ObamaYouTubers307.png 2x" width="250"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:ObamaYouTubers307.png" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         Leading YouTube content creators met at the White House with U.S. President Obama to discuss how government could better connect with the "YouTube generation".
         <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Tubefilter20140302_247-0">
          <a href="#cite_note-Tubefilter20140302-247">
           [247]
          </a>
         </sup>
         <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-WhiteHouse20140306_248-0">
          <a href="#cite_note-WhiteHouse20140306-248">
           [248]
          </a>
         </sup>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       Conversely, YouTube has also allowed government to more easily engage with citizens, the
       <a href="/wiki/White_House" title="White House">
        White House
       </a>
       's official YouTube channel being the seventh top news organization producer on YouTube in 2012
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-PewWhiteHouse20120716_249-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-PewWhiteHouse20120716-249">
         [249]
        </a>
       </sup>
       and in 2013 a healthcare exchange commissioned Obama impersonator
       <a href="/wiki/Iman_Crosson" title="Iman Crosson">
        Iman Crosson
       </a>
       's YouTube music video spoof to encourage young Americans to enroll in the
       <a href="/wiki/Patient_Protection_and_Affordable_Care_Act" title="Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act">
        Affordable Care Act (Obamacare)
       </a>
       -compliant health insurance.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-LATimes20131212_250-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-LATimes20131212-250">
         [250]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In February 2014, U.S. President Obama held a meeting at the White House with leading YouTube content creators to not only promote awareness of Obamacare
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Buzzfeed20140302_251-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Buzzfeed20140302-251">
         [251]
        </a>
       </sup>
       but more generally to develop ways for government to better connect with the "YouTube Generation".
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Tubefilter20140302_247-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-Tubefilter20140302-247">
         [247]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Whereas YouTube's inherent ability to allow presidents to directly connect with average citizens was noted, the YouTube content creators'
       <a href="/wiki/New_media" title="New media">
        new media
       </a>
       savvy was perceived necessary to better cope with the website's distracting content and fickle audience.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Tubefilter20140302_247-2">
        <a href="#cite_note-Tubefilter20140302-247">
         [247]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Some YouTube videos have themselves had a direct effect on world events, such as
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/Innocence_of_Muslims" title="Innocence of Muslims">
         Innocence of Muslims
        </a>
       </i>
       (2012) which spurred
       <a href="/wiki/Reactions_to_Innocence_of_Muslims" title="Reactions to Innocence of Muslims">
        protests and related anti-American violence
       </a>
       internationally.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CNN20120914_252-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-CNN20120914-252">
         [252]
        </a>
       </sup>
       TED curator Chris Anderson described a phenomenon by which geographically distributed individuals in a certain field share their independently developed skills in YouTube videos, thus challenging others to improve their own skills, and spurring invention and evolution in that field.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-TED201007Anderson_237-2">
        <a href="#cite_note-TED201007Anderson-237">
         [237]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Journalist
       <a href="/wiki/Virginia_Heffernan" title="Virginia Heffernan">
        Virginia Heffernan
       </a>
       stated in
       <i>
        The New York Times
       </i>
       that such videos have "surprising implications" for the dissemination of culture and even the future of classical music.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-253">
        <a href="#cite_note-253">
         [253]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/The_Legion_of_Extraordinary_Dancers" title="The Legion of Extraordinary Dancers">
         The Legion of Extraordinary Dancers
        </a>
       </i>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-TED201002LXD_254-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-TED201002LXD-254">
         [254]
        </a>
       </sup>
       and the
       <a href="/wiki/YouTube_Symphony_Orchestra" title="YouTube Symphony Orchestra">
        YouTube Symphony Orchestra
       </a>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Reuters20090414_255-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Reuters20090414-255">
         [255]
        </a>
       </sup>
       selected their membership based on individual video performances.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-TED201007Anderson_237-3">
        <a href="#cite_note-TED201007Anderson-237">
         [237]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Reuters20090414_255-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-Reuters20090414-255">
         [255]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Further, the cybercollaboration charity video "
       <a href="/wiki/We_Are_the_World_25_for_Haiti_(YouTube_edition)" title="We Are the World 25 for Haiti (YouTube edition)">
        We Are the World 25 for Haiti (YouTube edition)
       </a>
       " was formed by mixing performances of 57 globally distributed singers into a single musical work,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CNNtranscripts201003_256-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-CNNtranscripts201003-256">
         [256]
        </a>
       </sup>
       with
       <i>
        The Tokyo Times
       </i>
       noting the "We Pray for You" YouTube cyber-collaboration video as an example of a trend to use crowdsourcing for charitable purposes.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-TokyoTimes20110511_257-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-TokyoTimes20110511-257">
         [257]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The anti-bullying
       <a href="/wiki/It_Gets_Better_Project" title="It Gets Better Project">
        It Gets Better Project
       </a>
       expanded from a single YouTube video directed to discouraged or
       <a href="/wiki/Suicide_among_LGBT_youth" title="Suicide among LGBT youth">
        suicidal LGBT teens
       </a>
       ,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-SFChronicle20101008_258-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-SFChronicle20101008-258">
         [258]
        </a>
       </sup>
       that within two months drew video responses from hundreds including U.S. President Barack Obama, Vice President Biden, White House staff, and several cabinet secretaries.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-WhiteHouseItGetsBetter_259-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-WhiteHouseItGetsBetter-259">
         [259]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Similarly, in response to fifteen-year-old
       <a href="/wiki/Suicide_of_Amanda_Todd" title="Suicide of Amanda Todd">
        Amanda Todd
       </a>
       's video "My story: Struggling, bullying, suicide, self-harm", legislative action was undertaken almost immediately after her suicide to study the prevalence of bullying and form a national anti-bullying strategy.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CanadaTV20121014_260-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-CanadaTV20121014-260">
         [260]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h2>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Revenue">
        Revenue
       </span>
      </h2>
      <p>
       Google does not provide detailed figures for YouTube's running costs, and YouTube's revenues in 2007 were noted as "
       <a href="/wiki/Materiality_(auditing)" title="Materiality (auditing)">
        not material
       </a>
       " in a regulatory filing.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Moneyclip_261-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Moneyclip-261">
         [261]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In June 2008, a
       <i>
        Forbes
       </i>
       magazine article projected the 2008 revenue at $200 million, noting progress in advertising sales.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Forbes08_262-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Forbes08-262">
         [262]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In January 2012, it was estimated that visitors to YouTube spent an average of 15 minutes a day on the site, in contrast to the four or five hours a day spent by a typical US citizen watching television.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-seabrook20120116_29-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-seabrook20120116-29">
         [29]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In 2012, YouTube's revenue from its ads program was estimated at $3.7 billion.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Wall_Street_Journal_5.6_Billion_Annual_revenue_263-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Wall_Street_Journal_5.6_Billion_Annual_revenue-263">
         [263]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In 2013 it nearly doubled and estimated to hit $5.6 billion according to eMarketer,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Wall_Street_Journal_5.6_Billion_Annual_revenue_263-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-Wall_Street_Journal_5.6_Billion_Annual_revenue-263">
         [263]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Youtube_earns_5.6_Billion_Yahoo_264-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Youtube_earns_5.6_Billion_Yahoo-264">
         [264]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Forbes_YouTube_5.6_billion_2013_265-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Forbes_YouTube_5.6_billion_2013-265">
         [265]
        </a>
       </sup>
       others estimated 4.7 billion,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Wall_Street_Journal_5.6_Billion_Annual_revenue_263-2">
        <a href="#cite_note-Wall_Street_Journal_5.6_Billion_Annual_revenue-263">
         [263]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The vast majority of videos on YouTube are free to view and supported by advertising.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-subscription_56-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-subscription-56">
         [56]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In May 2013, YouTube introduced a trial scheme of 53 subscription channels with prices ranging from $0.99 to $6.99 a month.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-266">
        <a href="#cite_note-266">
         [266]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The move was seen as an attempt to compete with other providers of online subscription services such as
       <a href="/wiki/Netflix" title="Netflix">
        Netflix
       </a>
       and Hulu.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-subscription_56-2">
        <a href="#cite_note-subscription-56">
         [56]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In 2017, viewers watch YouTube on mobile devices for more than an hour every day.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-267">
        <a href="#cite_note-267">
         [267]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Advertisement_partnerships">
        Advertisement partnerships
       </span>
      </h3>
      <p>
       YouTube entered into a marketing and advertising partnership with
       <a href="/wiki/NBC" title="NBC">
        NBC
       </a>
       in June 2006.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-268">
        <a href="#cite_note-268">
         [268]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In March 2007, it struck a deal with
       <a href="/wiki/BBC" title="BBC">
        BBC
       </a>
       for three channels with BBC content, one for news and two for entertainment.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-269">
        <a href="#cite_note-269">
         [269]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In November 2008, YouTube reached an agreement with
       <a href="/wiki/Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer" title="Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer">
        MGM
       </a>
       ,
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Lions_Gate_Entertainment" title="Lions Gate Entertainment">
        Lions Gate Entertainment
       </a>
       , and
       <a href="/wiki/CBS" title="CBS">
        CBS
       </a>
       , allowing the companies to post full-length films and television episodes on the site, accompanied by advertisements in a section for US viewers called "Shows". The move was intended to create competition with websites such as Hulu, which features material from NBC,
       <a href="/wiki/Fox_Broadcasting_Company" title="Fox Broadcasting Company">
        Fox
       </a>
       , and
       <a href="/wiki/Walt_Disney_Studios_Motion_Pictures" title="Walt Disney Studios Motion Pictures">
        Disney
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-270">
        <a href="#cite_note-270">
         [270]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-271">
        <a href="#cite_note-271">
         [271]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In November 2009, YouTube launched a version of "Shows" available to UK viewers, offering around 4,000 full-length shows from more than 60 partners.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-272">
        <a href="#cite_note-272">
         [272]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In January 2010, YouTube introduced an online film rentals service,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-273">
        <a href="#cite_note-273">
         [273]
        </a>
       </sup>
       which is available only to users in the US, Canada and the UK as of 2010.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-274">
        <a href="#cite_note-274">
         [274]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-275">
        <a href="#cite_note-275">
         [275]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The service offers over 6,000 films.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-276">
        <a href="#cite_note-276">
         [276]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Partnership_with_video_creators">
        Partnership with video creators
       </span>
      </h3>
      <p>
       In May 2007, YouTube launched its Partner Program, a system based on
       <a href="/wiki/AdSense" title="AdSense">
        AdSense
       </a>
       which allows the uploader of the video to share the revenue produced by advertising on the site.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-277">
        <a href="#cite_note-277">
         [277]
        </a>
       </sup>
       YouTube typically takes 45 percent of the advertising revenue from videos in the Partner Program, with 55 percent going to the uploader.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-278">
        <a href="#cite_note-278">
         [278]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-279">
        <a href="#cite_note-279">
         [279]
        </a>
       </sup>
       There are over a million members of the YouTube Partner Program.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-280">
        <a href="#cite_note-280">
         [280]
        </a>
       </sup>
       According to
       <a href="/wiki/TubeMogul" title="TubeMogul">
        TubeMogul
       </a>
       , in 2013 a pre-roll advertisement on YouTube (one that is shown before the video starts) cost advertisers on average $7.60 per 1000 views. Usually no more than half of eligible videos have a pre-roll advertisement, due to a lack of interested advertisers.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-nyt_281-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-nyt-281">
         [281]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In 2013, YouTube introduced an option for channels with at least a thousand subscribers to require a paid subscription in order for viewers to watch videos.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-282">
        <a href="#cite_note-282">
         [282]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-283">
        <a href="#cite_note-283">
         [283]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In April 2017, YouTube set an eligibility requirement of 10,000 lifetime views for a paid subscription.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ypp_284-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-ypp-284">
         [284]
        </a>
       </sup>
       On January 16, 2018, the eligibility requirement for monetization was changed to 4,000 hours of watchtime within the past 12 months and 1,000 subscribers.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ypp_284-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-ypp-284">
         [284]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The move was seen as an attempt to ensure that videos being monetized did not lead to controversy, but was criticized for penalizing smaller YouTube channels.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ypp_guardian_285-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-ypp_guardian-285">
         [285]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <a href="/wiki/YouTube_Play_Button" title="YouTube Play Button">
        YouTube Play Buttons
       </a>
       , a part of the YouTube Creator Rewards, are a recognition by YouTube of its most popular channels.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-286">
        <a href="#cite_note-286">
         [286]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The trophies made of nickel plated copper-nickel alloy, golden plated brass, silver plated metal and ruby are given to channels with at least one hundred thousand, a million, ten million and fifty million subscribers, respectively.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-287">
        <a href="#cite_note-287">
         [287]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-288">
        <a href="#cite_note-288">
         [288]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Revenue_to_copyright_holders">
        Revenue to copyright holders
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Further information:
       <a href="#Copyrighted_material">
        § Copyrighted material
       </a>
      </div>
      <p>
       Much of YouTube's revenue goes to the copyright holders of the videos.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Forbes_YouTube_5.6_billion_2013_265-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-Forbes_YouTube_5.6_billion_2013-265">
         [265]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In 2010, it was reported that nearly a third of the videos with advertisements were uploaded without permission of the copyright holders. YouTube gives an option for copyright holders to locate and remove their videos or to have them continue running for revenue.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-289">
        <a href="#cite_note-289">
         [289]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In May 2013,
       <a href="/wiki/Nintendo" title="Nintendo">
        Nintendo
       </a>
       began enforcing its copyright ownership and claiming the advertising revenue from video creators who posted screenshots of its games.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-290">
        <a href="#cite_note-290">
         [290]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In February 2015, Nintendo agreed to share the revenue with the video creators.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-291">
        <a href="#cite_note-291">
         [291]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-292">
        <a href="#cite_note-292">
         [292]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-293">
        <a href="#cite_note-293">
         [293]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h2>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Community_policy">
        Community policy
       </span>
      </h2>
      <p>
       YouTube has a set of community guidelines aimed to reduce abuse of the site's features. Generally prohibited material includes sexually explicit content, videos of animal abuse,
       <a href="/wiki/Shock_site" title="Shock site">
        shock videos
       </a>
       , content uploaded without the copyright holder's consent, hate speech, spam, and predatory behavior.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-guidelines_294-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-guidelines-294">
         [294]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Despite the guidelines, YouTube has faced criticism from news sources for content in violation of these guidelines.
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Copyrighted_material">
        Copyrighted material
       </span>
      </h3>
      <p>
       At the time of uploading a video, YouTube users are shown a message asking them not to violate copyright laws.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-295">
        <a href="#cite_note-295">
         [295]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Despite this advice, there are still many unauthorized clips of copyrighted material on YouTube. YouTube does not view videos before they are posted online, and it is left to copyright holders to issue a
       <a href="/wiki/Digital_Millennium_Copyright_Act" title="Digital Millennium Copyright Act">
        DMCA
       </a>
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Takedown_notice" title="Takedown notice">
        takedown notice
       </a>
       pursuant to the terms of the
       <a href="/wiki/Online_Copyright_Infringement_Liability_Limitation_Act" title="Online Copyright Infringement Liability Limitation Act">
        Online Copyright Infringement Liability Limitation Act
       </a>
       . Any successful complaint about copyright infringement results in a
       <a href="/wiki/YouTube_copyright_strike" title="YouTube copyright strike">
        YouTube copyright strike
       </a>
       . Three successful complaints for
       <a href="/wiki/Copyright_infringement" title="Copyright infringement">
        copyright infringement
       </a>
       against a user account will result in the account and all of its uploaded videos being deleted.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-296">
        <a href="#cite_note-296">
         [296]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-297">
        <a href="#cite_note-297">
         [297]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Organizations including
       <a href="/wiki/Viacom" title="Viacom">
        Viacom
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Mediaset" title="Mediaset">
        Mediaset
       </a>
       , and the English
       <a href="/wiki/Premier_League" title="Premier League">
        Premier League
       </a>
       have filed lawsuits against YouTube, claiming that it has done too little to prevent the uploading of copyrighted material.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-298">
        <a href="#cite_note-298">
         [298]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-299">
        <a href="#cite_note-299">
         [299]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-300">
        <a href="#cite_note-300">
         [300]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Viacom, demanding $1 billion in damages, said that it had found more than 150,000 unauthorized clips of its material on YouTube that had been viewed "an astounding 1.5 billion times". YouTube responded by stating that it "goes far beyond its legal obligations in assisting content owners to protect their works".
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-301">
        <a href="#cite_note-301">
         [301]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       During the same court battle, Viacom won a court ruling requiring YouTube to hand over 12 terabytes of data detailing the viewing habits of every user who has watched videos on the site. The decision was criticized by the
       <a href="/wiki/Electronic_Frontier_Foundation" title="Electronic Frontier Foundation">
        Electronic Frontier Foundation
       </a>
       , which called the court ruling "a setback to privacy rights".
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-privacy_bbc_302-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-privacy_bbc-302">
         [302]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-303">
        <a href="#cite_note-303">
         [303]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In June 2010, Viacom's lawsuit against Google was rejected in a summary judgment, with U.S. federal Judge
       <a href="/wiki/Louis_L._Stanton" title="Louis L. Stanton">
        Louis L. Stanton
       </a>
       stating that Google was protected by provisions of the Digital Millennium Copyright Act. Viacom announced its intention to appeal the ruling.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-304">
        <a href="#cite_note-304">
         [304]
        </a>
       </sup>
       On April 5, 2012, the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit reinstated the case, allowing Viacom's lawsuit against Google to be heard in court again.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-305">
        <a href="#cite_note-305">
         [305]
        </a>
       </sup>
       On March 18, 2014, the lawsuit was settled after seven years with an undisclosed agreement.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-306">
        <a href="#cite_note-306">
         [306]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       In August 2008, a US court ruled in
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/Lenz_v._Universal_Music_Corp." title="Lenz v. Universal Music Corp.">
         Lenz v. Universal Music Corp.
        </a>
       </i>
       that copyright holders cannot order the removal of an online file without first determining whether the posting reflected
       <a href="/wiki/Fair_use" title="Fair use">
        fair use
       </a>
       of the material. The case involved Stephanie Lenz from Gallitzin, Pennsylvania, who had made a home video of her 13-month-old son dancing to
       <a href="/wiki/Prince_(musician)" title="Prince (musician)">
        Prince
       </a>
       's song "
       <a href="/wiki/Let%27s_Go_Crazy" title="Let's Go Crazy">
        Let's Go Crazy
       </a>
       ", and posted the 29-second video on YouTube.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-307">
        <a href="#cite_note-307">
         [307]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In the case of
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/Smith_v._Summit_Entertainment_LLC" title="Smith v. Summit Entertainment LLC">
         Smith v. Summit Entertainment LLC
        </a>
       </i>
       , professional singer Matt Smith sued Summit Entertainment for the wrongful use of copyright takedown notices on YouTube.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-308">
        <a href="#cite_note-308">
         [308]
        </a>
       </sup>
       He asserted seven
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Causes_of_action" title="Causes of action">
        causes of action
       </a>
       , and four were ruled in Smith's favor.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-309">
        <a href="#cite_note-309">
         [309]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       In April 2012, a court in Hamburg ruled that YouTube could be held responsible for copyrighted material posted by its users. The performance rights organization
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Gesellschaft_f%C3%BCr_musikalische_Auff%C3%BChrungs-_und_mechanische_Vervielf%C3%A4ltigungsrechte" title="Gesellschaft für musikalische Aufführungs- und mechanische Vervielfältigungsrechte">
        GEMA
       </a>
       argued that YouTube had not done enough to prevent the uploading of German copyrighted music. YouTube responded by stating:
      </p>
      <table class="cquote pullquote" role="presentation" style="margin:auto; border-collapse: collapse; border: none; background-color: transparent; width: auto;">
       <tr>
        <td style="width: 20px; vertical-align: top; border: none; color: #B2B7F2; font-size: 40px; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times, serif; font-weight: bold; line-height: .6em; text-align: left; padding: 10px 10px;">
         “
        </td>
        <td style="vertical-align: top; border: none; padding: 4px 10px;">
         <i>
          We remain committed to finding a solution to the music licensing issue in Germany that will benefit artists, composers, authors, publishers and record labels, as well as the wider YouTube community
         </i>
         .
         <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-310">
          <a href="#cite_note-310">
           [310]
          </a>
         </sup>
        </td>
        <td style="width: 20px; vertical-align: bottom; border: none; color: #B2B7F2; font-size: 40px; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times, serif; font-weight: bold; line-height: .6em; text-align: right; padding: 10px 10px;">
         ”
        </td>
       </tr>
      </table>
      <p>
       On November 1, 2016, the dispute with GEMA was resolved, with Google content ID being used to allow advertisements to be added to videos with content protected by GEMA.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-311">
        <a href="#cite_note-311">
         [311]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       In April 2013, it was reported that
       <a href="/wiki/Universal_Music_Group" title="Universal Music Group">
        Universal Music Group
       </a>
       and YouTube have a contractual agreement that prevents content blocked on YouTube by a request from UMG from being restored, even if the uploader of the video files a DMCA counter-notice. When a dispute occurs, the uploader of the video has to contact UMG.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-312">
        <a href="#cite_note-312">
         [312]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-313">
        <a href="#cite_note-313">
         [313]
        </a>
       </sup>
       YouTube's owner Google announced in November 2015 that they would help cover the legal cost in select cases where they believe "fair use" laws apply.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-314">
        <a href="#cite_note-314">
         [314]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h4>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Content_ID">
        Content ID
       </span>
      </h4>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       See also:
       <a href="/wiki/Criticism_of_Google#YouTube" title="Criticism of Google">
        Criticism of Google § YouTube
       </a>
      </div>
      <p>
       In June 2007, YouTube began trials of a system for automatic detection of uploaded videos that infringe copyright. Google CEO Eric Schmidt regarded this system as necessary for resolving lawsuits such as the one from
       <a href="/wiki/Viacom" title="Viacom">
        Viacom
       </a>
       , which alleged that YouTube profited from content that it did not have the right to distribute.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-315">
        <a href="#cite_note-315">
         [315]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The system, which became known as Content ID,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-316">
        <a href="#cite_note-316">
         [316]
        </a>
       </sup>
       creates an ID File for copyrighted audio and video material, and stores it in a database. When a video is uploaded, it is checked against the database, and flags the video as a copyright violation if a match is found.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-youtube_317-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-youtube-317">
         [317]
        </a>
       </sup>
       When this occurs, the content owner has the choice of blocking the video to make it unviewable, tracking the viewing statistics of the video, or adding advertisements to the video. YouTube describes Content ID as "very accurate in finding uploads that look similar to reference files that are of sufficient length and quality to generate an effective ID File".
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-youtube_317-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-youtube-317">
         [317]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Content ID accounts for over a third of the monetized views on YouTube.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-318">
        <a href="#cite_note-318">
         [318]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       An independent test in 2009 uploaded multiple versions of the same song to YouTube, and concluded that while the system was "surprisingly resilient" in finding copyright violations in the audio tracks of videos, it was not infallible.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-319">
        <a href="#cite_note-319">
         [319]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The use of Content ID to remove material automatically has led to
       <a href="/wiki/YouTube_copyright_issues" title="YouTube copyright issues">
        controversy
       </a>
       in some cases, as the videos have not been checked by a human for fair use.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-320">
        <a href="#cite_note-320">
         [320]
        </a>
       </sup>
       If a YouTube user disagrees with a decision by Content ID, it is possible to fill in a form disputing the decision.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-321">
        <a href="#cite_note-321">
         [321]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Prior to 2016, videos weren't monetized until the dispute was resolved. Since April 2016, videos continue to be monetized while the dispute is in progress, and the money goes to whoever won the dispute.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-322">
        <a href="#cite_note-322">
         [322]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Should the uploader want to monetize the video again, they may remove the disputed audio in the "Video Manager".
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-323">
        <a href="#cite_note-323">
         [323]
        </a>
       </sup>
       YouTube has cited the effectiveness of Content ID as one of the reasons why the site's rules were modified in December 2010 to allow some users to upload videos of unlimited length.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-324">
        <a href="#cite_note-324">
         [324]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Controversial_content">
        Controversial content
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       See also:
       <a href="/wiki/Criticism_of_Google#YouTube" title="Criticism of Google">
        Criticism of Google § YouTube
       </a>
       , and
       <a href="/wiki/Censorship_by_Google#YouTube" title="Censorship by Google">
        Censorship by Google § YouTube
       </a>
      </div>
      <p>
       YouTube has also faced criticism over the handling of offensive content in some of its videos. The uploading of videos containing defamation, pornography, and material encouraging criminal conduct is forbidden by YouTube's "Community Guidelines".
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-guidelines_294-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-guidelines-294">
         [294]
        </a>
       </sup>
       YouTube relies on its users to flag the content of videos as inappropriate, and a YouTube employee will view a flagged video to determine whether it violates the site's guidelines.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-guidelines_294-2">
        <a href="#cite_note-guidelines-294">
         [294]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Controversial content has included material relating to
       <a href="/wiki/Holocaust_denial" title="Holocaust denial">
        Holocaust denial
       </a>
       and the
       <a href="/wiki/Hillsborough_disaster" title="Hillsborough disaster">
        Hillsborough disaster
       </a>
       , in which 96 football fans from Liverpool were crushed to death in 1989.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-325">
        <a href="#cite_note-325">
         [325]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-326">
        <a href="#cite_note-326">
         [326]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In July 2008, the Culture and Media Committee of the House of Commons of the United Kingdom stated that it was "unimpressed" with YouTube's system for policing its videos, and argued that "proactive review of content should be standard practice for sites hosting user-generated content". YouTube responded by stating:
      </p>
      <blockquote class="templatequote">
       <p>
        We have strict rules on what's allowed, and a system that enables anyone who sees inappropriate content to report it to our 24/7 review team and have it dealt with promptly. We educate our community on the rules and include a direct link from every YouTube page to make this process as easy as possible for our users. Given the volume of content uploaded on our site, we think this is by far the most effective way to make sure that the tiny minority of videos that break the rules come down quickly.
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-327">
         <a href="#cite_note-327">
          [327]
         </a>
        </sup>
        (July 2008)
       </p>
      </blockquote>
      <p>
       In October 2010, U.S. Congressman
       <a href="/wiki/Anthony_Weiner" title="Anthony Weiner">
        Anthony Weiner
       </a>
       urged YouTube to remove from its website videos of imam
       <a href="/wiki/Anwar_al-Awlaki" title="Anwar al-Awlaki">
        Anwar al-Awlaki
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-328">
        <a href="#cite_note-328">
         [328]
        </a>
       </sup>
       YouTube pulled some of the videos in November 2010, stating they violated the site's guidelines.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-329">
        <a href="#cite_note-329">
         [329]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In December 2010, YouTube added the ability to flag videos for containing terrorism content.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-330">
        <a href="#cite_note-330">
         [330]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Following media reports about
       <a href="/wiki/PRISM_(surveillance_program)" title="PRISM (surveillance program)">
        PRISM
       </a>
       , NSA's massive electronic surveillance program, in June 2013, several technology companies were identified as participants, including YouTube. According to leaks of said program, YouTube joined the PRISM program in 2010.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-331">
        <a href="#cite_note-331">
         [331]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       YouTube's policies on "
       <a href="/wiki/Censorship_of_YouTube#Advertiser-friendly_content" title="Censorship of YouTube">
        advertiser-friendly content
       </a>
       " restrict what may be incorporated into videos being monetized; this includes strong violence, language, sexual content, and "controversial or sensitive subjects and events, including subjects related to war, political conflicts, natural disasters and tragedies, even if graphic imagery is not shown", unless the content is "usually newsworthy or comedic and the creator's intent is to inform or entertain".
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-332">
        <a href="#cite_note-332">
         [332]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In September 2016, after introducing an enhanced notification system to inform users of these violations, YouTube's policies were criticized by prominent users, including
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Phillip_DeFranco" title="Phillip DeFranco">
        Phillip DeFranco
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Vlogbrothers" title="Vlogbrothers">
        Vlogbrothers
       </a>
       . DeFranco argued that not being able to earn advertising revenue on such videos was "censorship by a different name". A YouTube spokesperson stated that while the policy itself was not new, the service had "improved the notification and appeal process to ensure better communication to our creators".
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-333">
        <a href="#cite_note-333">
         [333]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-334">
        <a href="#cite_note-334">
         [334]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-335">
        <a href="#cite_note-335">
         [335]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       <span id="Advertiser_boycott">
       </span>
       In March 2017, the government of the United Kingdom pulled its advertising campaigns from YouTube, after reports that its ads had appeared on videos containing extremism content. The government demanded assurances that its advertising would "be delivered in a safe and appropriate way".
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/The_Guardian" title="The Guardian">
         The Guardian
        </a>
       </i>
       newspaper, as well as other major British and U.S. brands, similarly suspended their advertising on YouTube in response to their advertising appearing near offensive content. Google stated that it had "begun an extensive review of our advertising policies and have made a public commitment to put in place changes that give brands more control over where their ads appear".
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-bloomberg-adsextremist_336-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-bloomberg-adsextremist-336">
         [336]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-bbc-youtubeadsuk_337-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-bbc-youtubeadsuk-337">
         [337]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In early-April 2017, the YouTube channel
       <a href="/wiki/H3h3Productions" title="H3h3Productions">
        h3h3Productions
       </a>
       presented evidence claiming that a
       <i>
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Wall_Street_Journal" title="Wall Street Journal">
         Wall Street Journal
        </a>
       </i>
       article had fabricated screenshots showing major brand advertising on an offensive video containing
       <a href="/wiki/Johnny_Rebel_(singer)" title="Johnny Rebel (singer)">
        Johnny Rebel
       </a>
       music overlaid on a
       <a href="/wiki/Chief_Keef" title="Chief Keef">
        Chief Keef
       </a>
       music video, citing that the video itself had not earned any ad revenue for the uploader. The video was retracted after it was found that the ads had actually been triggered by the use of copyrighted content in the video.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-tdb-youtubestar_338-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-tdb-youtubestar-338">
         [338]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-mashable-h3h3youtube_339-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-mashable-h3h3youtube-339">
         [339]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       On April 6, 2017, YouTube announced that in order to "ensure revenue only flows to creators who are playing by the rules", it would change its practices to require that a channel undergo a policy compliance review, and have at least 10,000 lifetime views, before they may join the Partner Program.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-verge-10kviewsrule_340-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-verge-10kviewsrule-340">
         [340]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h4>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Child_protection">
        Child protection
       </span>
      </h4>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       See also:
       <a href="/wiki/DaddyOFive" title="DaddyOFive">
        DaddyOFive
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Elsagate" title="Elsagate">
        Elsagate
       </a>
      </div>
      <p>
       In 2017, YouTube was associated with several controversies related to
       <a href="/wiki/Child_protection" title="Child protection">
        child safety
       </a>
       . During Q2, the owners of popular channel
       <a href="/wiki/DaddyOFive" title="DaddyOFive">
        DaddyOFive
       </a>
       , which featured themselves playing "pranks" on their children, were accused of
       <a href="/wiki/Child_abuse" title="Child abuse">
        child abuse
       </a>
       . Their videos were eventually deleted, and two of their children were removed from their custody.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ohlheiser2017_341-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Ohlheiser2017-341">
         [341]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Cresci2017_342-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Cresci2017-342">
         [342]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Dunphy2017_343-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Dunphy2017-343">
         [343]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Gajanan2017_344-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Gajanan2017-344">
         [344]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Later that year, YouTube came under criticism for showing inappropriate videos targeted at children and often featuring popular characters in violent, sexual or otherwise disturbing situations, many of which appeared on
       <a href="/wiki/YouTube_Kids" title="YouTube Kids">
        YouTube Kids
       </a>
       and attracted millions of views. The term "
       <a href="/wiki/Elsagate" title="Elsagate">
        Elsagate
       </a>
       " was coined on the Internet and then used by various news outlets to refer to this controversy.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-345">
        <a href="#cite_note-345">
         [345]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-346">
        <a href="#cite_note-346">
         [346]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NYT_347-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-NYT-347">
         [347]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-forbes_348-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-forbes-348">
         [348]
        </a>
       </sup>
       On November 11, 2017, YouTube announced it was strengthening site security to protect children from unsuitable content. Later that month, the company started to mass delete videos and channels which made improper use of family friendly characters. As part as a broader concern regarding child safety on YouTube, the wave of deletions also targeted channels which showed children taking part in inappropriate or dangerous activities under the guidance of adults. Most notably, the company removed
       <i>
        Toy Freaks
       </i>
       , a channel with over 8.5 million subscribers, that featured a father and his two daughters in odd and upsetting situations.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-349">
        <a href="#cite_note-349">
         [349]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-verge_350-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-verge-350">
         [350]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-351">
        <a href="#cite_note-351">
         [351]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-352">
        <a href="#cite_note-352">
         [352]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-353">
        <a href="#cite_note-353">
         [353]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-354">
        <a href="#cite_note-354">
         [354]
        </a>
       </sup>
       According to analytics specialist SocialBlade, it earned up to £8.7 million annually prior to its deletion.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-355">
        <a href="#cite_note-355">
         [355]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Also in November 2017, it was revealed in the media that many videos featuring children – often uploaded by the minors themselves, and showing innocent content – were attracting comments from
       <a href="/wiki/Pedophilia" title="Pedophilia">
        pedophiles
       </a>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-356">
        <a href="#cite_note-356">
         [356]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-habits_357-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-habits-357">
         [357]
        </a>
       </sup>
       and circulating on the
       <a href="/wiki/Dark_web" title="Dark web">
        dark web
       </a>
       , with predators finding the videos by typing in certain keywords in Russian.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-habits_357-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-habits-357">
         [357]
        </a>
       </sup>
       As a result of the controversy, which added to the concern about "Elsagate", several major advertisers whose ads had been running against such videos froze spending on YouTube.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-358">
        <a href="#cite_note-358">
         [358]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-forbes_348-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-forbes-348">
         [348]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="User_comments">
        User comments
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       See also:
       <a href="/wiki/Criticism_of_Google#YouTube_user_comments" title="Criticism of Google">
        Criticism of Google § YouTube user comments
       </a>
      </div>
      <p>
       Most videos enable users to leave comments, and these have attracted attention for the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Troll_(Internet)" title="Troll (Internet)">
        negative
       </a>
       aspects of both their form and content. In 2006,
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/Time_(magazine)" title="Time (magazine)">
         Time
        </a>
       </i>
       praised
       <a href="/wiki/Web_2.0" title="Web 2.0">
        Web 2.0
       </a>
       for enabling "community and collaboration on a scale never seen before", and added that YouTube "harnesses the stupidity of crowds as well as its wisdom. Some of the comments on YouTube make you weep for the future of humanity just for the spelling alone, never mind the obscenity and the naked hatred".
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-359">
        <a href="#cite_note-359">
         [359]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/The_Guardian" title="The Guardian">
         The Guardian
        </a>
       </i>
       in 2009 described users' comments on YouTube as:
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-360">
        <a href="#cite_note-360">
         [360]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <blockquote class="templatequote">
       <p>
        Juvenile, aggressive, misspelled, sexist, homophobic, swinging from raging at the contents of a video to providing a pointlessly detailed description followed by a LOL, YouTube comments are a hotbed of infantile debate and unashamed ignorance – with the occasional burst of wit shining through.
       </p>
      </blockquote>
      <p>
       In September 2008,
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/The_Daily_Telegraph" title="The Daily Telegraph">
         The Daily Telegraph
        </a>
       </i>
       commented that YouTube was "notorious" for "some of the most confrontational and ill-formed comment exchanges on the internet", and reported on YouTube Comment Snob, "a new piece of software that blocks rude and illiterate posts".
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-361">
        <a href="#cite_note-361">
         [361]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <i>
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/The_Huffington_Post" title="The Huffington Post">
         The Huffington Post
        </a>
       </i>
       noted in April 2012 that finding comments on YouTube that appear "offensive, stupid and crass" to the "vast majority" of the people is hardly difficult.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-362">
        <a href="#cite_note-362">
         [362]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       On November 6, 2013, Google implemented a comment system oriented on Google+ that required all YouTube users to use a Google+ account in order to comment on videos. The stated motivation for the change was giving creators more power to moderate and block comments, thereby addressing frequent criticisms of their quality and tone.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-363">
        <a href="#cite_note-363">
         [363]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The new system restored the ability to include
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Uniform_resource_locator" title="Uniform resource locator">
        URLs
       </a>
       in comments, which had previously been removed due to problems with abuse.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-364">
        <a href="#cite_note-364">
         [364]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-365">
        <a href="#cite_note-365">
         [365]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In response, YouTube co-founder Jawed Karim posted the question "why the fuck do I need a google+ account to comment on a video?" on his YouTube channel to express his negative opinion of the change.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-366">
        <a href="#cite_note-366">
         [366]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The official YouTube announcement
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-367">
        <a href="#cite_note-367">
         [367]
        </a>
       </sup>
       received 20,097 "thumbs down" votes and generated more than 32,000 comments in two days.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-368">
        <a href="#cite_note-368">
         [368]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Writing in the
       <i>
        Newsday
       </i>
       blog Silicon Island, Chase Melvin noted that "Google+ is nowhere near as popular a social media network as Facebook, but it's essentially being forced upon millions of YouTube users who don't want to lose their ability to comment on videos" and "Discussion forums across the Internet are already bursting with outcry against the new comment system". In the same article Melvin goes on to say:
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-369">
        <a href="#cite_note-369">
         [369]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <blockquote class="templatequote">
       <p>
        Perhaps user complaints are justified, but the idea of revamping the old system isn't so bad.
       </p>
       <p>
        Think of the crude, misogynistic and racially-charged mudslinging that has transpired over the last eight years on YouTube without any discernible moderation. Isn't any attempt to curb unidentified libelers worth a shot? The system is far from perfect, but Google should be lauded for trying to alleviate some of the damage caused by irate YouTubers hiding behind animosity and anonymity.
       </p>
      </blockquote>
      <p>
       On July 27, 2015, Google announced in a blog post that it would be removing the requirement to sign up to a Google+ account to post comments to YouTube.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-370">
        <a href="#cite_note-370">
         [370]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       On November 3, 2016, YouTube announced a trial scheme which allows the creators of videos to decide whether to approve, hide or report the comments posted on videos based on an
       <a href="/wiki/Algorithm" title="Algorithm">
        algorithm
       </a>
       that detects potentially offensive comments.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-371">
        <a href="#cite_note-371">
         [371]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Creators may also choose to keep or delete comments with links or hashtags in order to combat spam. They can also allow other users to moderate their comments.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-372">
        <a href="#cite_note-372">
         [372]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="View_counts">
        View counts
       </span>
      </h3>
      <p>
       In December 2012, two billion views were removed from the view counts of Universal and
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sony_Music_Entertainment" title="Sony Music Entertainment">
        Sony
       </a>
       music videos on YouTube, prompting a claim by
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/The_Daily_Dot" title="The Daily Dot">
         The Daily Dot
        </a>
       </i>
       that the views had been deleted due to a violation of the site's terms of service, which ban the use of automated processes to inflate view counts. This was disputed by
       <i>
        Billboard
       </i>
       , which said that the two billion views had been moved to Vevo, since the videos were no longer active on YouTube.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-daily_dot_373-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-daily_dot-373">
         [373]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-guardian_migrate_374-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-guardian_migrate-374">
         [374]
        </a>
       </sup>
       On August 5, 2015, YouTube removed the feature which caused a video's view count to freeze at "301" (later "301+") until the actual count was verified to prevent
       <a href="/wiki/Click_fraud" title="Click fraud">
        view count fraud
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-375">
        <a href="#cite_note-375">
         [375]
        </a>
       </sup>
       YouTube view counts once again updated in real time.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-376">
        <a href="#cite_note-376">
         [376]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h2>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Censorship_and_filtering">
        Censorship and filtering
       </span>
      </h2>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/Censorship_of_YouTube" title="Censorship of YouTube">
        Censorship of YouTube
       </a>
      </div>
      <p>
       As of 2017
       <sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;">
        <a class="external text" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=YouTube&amp;action=edit">
         [update]
        </a>
       </sup>
       , countries with standing national bans on YouTube are
       <a href="/wiki/China" title="China">
        China
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/North_Korea" title="North Korea">
        North Korea
       </a>
       , while
       <a href="/wiki/Iran" title="Iran">
        Iran
       </a>
       blocks YouTube on only one
       <a href="/wiki/Internet_service_provider" title="Internet service provider">
        internet service provider
       </a>
       .
      </p>
      <p>
       YouTube may be blocked for a variety of reasons, including:
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ONIYouTubeCensored_377-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-ONIYouTubeCensored-377">
         [377]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <ul>
       <li>
        Limiting public exposure to content that may ignite social or political unrest;
       </li>
       <li>
        Preventing criticism of a ruler (e.g. in
        <a href="/wiki/North_Korea" title="North Korea">
         North Korea
        </a>
        ), government (e.g. in
        <a href="/wiki/China" title="China">
         China
        </a>
        ) or its actions (e.g. in
        <a href="/wiki/Morocco" title="Morocco">
         Morocco
        </a>
        ), government officials (e.g. in
        <a href="/wiki/Turkey" title="Turkey">
         Turkey
        </a>
        and
        <a href="/wiki/Libya" title="Libya">
         Libya
        </a>
        ), or religion (e.g. in
        <a href="/wiki/Pakistan" title="Pakistan">
         Pakistan
        </a>
        );
       </li>
       <li>
        Violations of national laws, including:
        <ul>
         <li>
          Copyright and intellectual property protection laws, for example
          <a href="/wiki/Blocking_of_YouTube_videos_in_Germany" title="Blocking of YouTube videos in Germany">
           in Germany
          </a>
          ;
         </li>
         <li>
          Violations of hate speech, ethics, or morality-based laws, e.g. in
          <a href="/wiki/Iran" title="Iran">
           Iran
          </a>
          ; and
         </li>
        </ul>
       </li>
       <li>
        Preventing access to videos judged to be inappropriate for youth,
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-378">
         <a href="#cite_note-378">
          [378]
         </a>
        </sup>
        which is also done by YouTube with the
        <a href="/wiki/YouTube_Kids" title="YouTube Kids">
         YouTube Kids
        </a>
        app and with "
        <a href="/wiki/Censorship_of_YouTube#Censorship_of_LGBT_content_in_Restricted_Mode" title="Censorship of YouTube">
         Restricted mode
        </a>
        ";
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-379">
         <a href="#cite_note-379">
          [379]
         </a>
        </sup>
       </li>
       <li>
        Reducing distractions at work or school,
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-380">
         <a href="#cite_note-380">
          [380]
         </a>
        </sup>
        e.g. in
        <a href="/wiki/Australia" title="Australia">
         Australia
        </a>
        ; and
       </li>
       <li>
        Reducing the amount of network bandwidth used.
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-381">
         <a href="#cite_note-381">
          [381]
         </a>
        </sup>
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-382">
         <a href="#cite_note-382">
          [382]
         </a>
        </sup>
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-383">
         <a href="#cite_note-383">
          [383]
         </a>
        </sup>
       </li>
      </ul>
      <p>
       In some countries, YouTube is completely blocked, either through a long term standing ban or for more limited periods of time such as during periods of unrest, the run-up to an election, or in response to upcoming political anniversaries. In other countries access to the website as a whole remains open, but access to specific videos is blocked. In cases where the entire site is banned due to one particular video, YouTube will often agree to remove or limit access to that video in order to restore service. Businesses, schools, government agencies, and other private institutions often block social media sites, including YouTube, due to bandwidth limitations and the site's potential for distraction.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ONIYouTubeCensored_377-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-ONIYouTubeCensored-377">
         [377]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Several countries have previously blocked access to YouTube:
      </p>
      <ul>
       <li>
        Iran temporarily blocked access on December 3, 2006, to YouTube and several other sites, after declaring them as violating social and moral codes of conduct. The YouTube block came after a video was posted online that appeared to show an Iranian soap opera star having sex.
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-384">
         <a href="#cite_note-384">
          [384]
         </a>
        </sup>
        The block was later lifted and then reinstated after
        <a href="/wiki/Iranian_presidential_election,_2009" title="Iranian presidential election, 2009">
         Iran's 2009 presidential election
        </a>
        .
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-385">
         <a href="#cite_note-385">
          [385]
         </a>
        </sup>
        In 2012, Iran reblocked access, along with access to Google, after the controversial film
        <i>
         <a href="/wiki/Innocence_of_Muslims" title="Innocence of Muslims">
          Innocence of Muslims
         </a>
        </i>
        trailer was released on YouTube.
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-386">
         <a href="#cite_note-386">
          [386]
         </a>
        </sup>
       </li>
       <li>
        <a href="/wiki/Thailand" title="Thailand">
